Name: Center for Service in Action
Description:
Learn by Doing Good!

 

Mission: The Center for Service in Action (CSA) at Cal Poly connects students with meaningful community service opportunities that complement their educational experience, strengthen their understanding of diversity and social responsibility, and develop skills to become ethical and knowledgeable leaders who contribute to a global society. The CSA cultivates reciprocal service and learning partnerships between the university and community partner agencies, serving community-based organizations and governmental institutions seeking University support to address unmet community needs.

       

Programs: Through a variety of programs, events, and workshops, we empower students to make positive changes in their communities through service and leadership. Our offerings include:

  • Service events with community partners
  • Volunteer matchmaking
  • Change the Status Quo (social justice leadership conference)
  • Service Learning
  • Alternative Breaks
  • AmeriCorps and Service Year programs

Visit our website for more information!
Summary: The Center for Service in Action at Cal Poly empowers students to take action and address community needs through service, volunteering, and activism.

Name: Cerro Vista Apartments
Description:
Perched at the base of the northeast hillside of campus, the Cerro Vista Apartment community overlooks Cal Poly, offering gorgeous views and easy access to nearby hiking trails. Each apartment provides direct outdoor access and has a full kitchen, living room common area, two suite-style bathrooms, and four private bedrooms. Apartment are separated by gender unless the student specifically requests Queer-affirming housing.

 

The Cerro Vista Apartments are made up of six adjoining residence buildings named after the hills which span from San Luis Obispo to Morro Bay:


• Morro
• Cabrillo
• Hollister
• Romauldo
• Islay
• Bishop

 

The community center includes a game room, study lounge, private study rooms, and a community kitchen.

 

Cerro Vista Apartments Virtual Tour

 

Map & Photos
Summary: Cerro Vista Apartments - Student Group: First years, transfer and graduate students

Name: Chabad Student Group
Description: Chabad is an organization that offers a “home away from home” to Jewish students regardless of background, level of observance or affiliation. Students come to the Chabad House for a variety of things such as a bowl of homemade chicken soup, fresh baked challah at weekly Shabbat dinners; classes such as Sinai Scholars, social action projects, a place to socialize and relax with other Jewish students, a discreet, sympathetic ear, a warm heart, a smile and a hug, and appropriate guidance or referrals when needed, and to celebrate holidays. We love the jewish community here at Cal Poly and hope to meet you!
Summary: Chabad Student Group of Cal Poly is a Jewish organization that provides students with a ''home away from home''. Chabad is dedicated to increasing the awareness, knowledge and tradition of Judaism in the Central Coast

Name: Chi Delta Theta Sorority, Incorporated
Description:
What is Chi Delta Theta? 
Chi Delta Theta Sorority Inc. is an Asian-American interest sorority established on October 13, 1989, at the University of California, Santa Barbara by founding mothers Alison Suto-Stripling and Joanne Yamaoka.

As members of Chi Delta Theta, we strive to promote siblinghood, academics, community service, cultural awareness, and social activity in the lives of our members. Together, our goals are to unite Asian clubs and organizations, educate and enhance the learning of Asian culture, encourage interaction between cultural fraternities and sororities, and provide a support network for our members by developing a special bond of family, loyalty, and commitment.

Over the past 25 years, Chi Delta Theta has expanded to include eight chapters, with over 500 members across California.

Α - University of California, Santa Barbara
Β - CALIFORNIA POLYTECHNIC STATE UNIVERSITY, SAN LUIS OBISPO
Γ - Loyola Marymount University
Δ - California State University, Long Beach
Ε - University of California, Davis
Z - University of California, Los Angeles
H - California State University, Northridge
Θ - University of California, San Diego 
 
Although Chi Delta Theta only consists of eight chapters, don't underestimate our bond! We pride ourselves in knowing each and every sibling from each chapter. This provides us with a support network of close friends everywhere we go. 

For more information, visit our website (http://slochidelts.wixsite.com/calpolyslo) and our instagram/facebook @slochidelts!
 
Please visit our Instagram or reach out to a sib for upcoming rush info if you are interested in joining!
Summary: Chi Delta Theta strives to promote siblinghood, academics, community service, cultural awareness, and social activity in the lives of its members.

Name: Chi Epsilon Honor Society
Description:
About

Chi Epsilon is a tight-knit group of like-minded dedicated civil and environmental engineers. Our small size and great reputation allow us to provide members with plenty of opportunities to demonstrate and learn professionalism, leadership, and networking. Chi Epsilon at Cal Poly is only one chapter of a prestigious organization spanning the nation composed of not only students but, alumni and other civil and environmental engineering professionals. We work to serve the world around us and allow engineers to achieve their full potential.

 

FE Review Sessions

Chi Epsilon offers FE Review Sessions to all who are interested, contingent on a small fee. Review lectures from Cal Poly professors are made available on canvas. The FE review sessions cover a wide range of Civil Engineering topics found on the exam. Some in-person review sessions may be reintroduced later in the year. Non-members are required to pay $40 and members are required to pay $20 for access to this service. To sign-up or get more information please contact ccamerin@calpoly.edu.

 

Requirements for Membership

Invitations are hinged on two prerequisites. Firstly, you must be a Civil or Environmental Engineer of at least Sophomore standing. Secondly, you must hold a GPA in the top third of Civil and Environmental Engineers at Cal Poly

Should you choose to accept an invitation from Chi Epsilon, you'll take part in a quarter-long initiation. During the process, you will be asked to demonstrate the principles of "Scholarship, Character, Practicality, and Sociability".

 

If you have any questions please contact: xecalpoly@gmail.com

External website: calpolychiepsilon.weebly.com

Instagram: @calpolychiepsilon
Summary: Chi Epsilon is the National Civil Engineering Honor Society in the United States. We honor students who have exemplified the principles of "Scholarship, Character, Practicality, and Sociability" in the civil and environmental engineering profession.

Name: Chi Psi Chapter of Alpha Omicron Pi
Description:
Thank you for taking the time to explore our page and what it means to be
an Alpha Omicron Pi at Cal Poly San Luis Obispo. In the Chi Psi Chapter, we strive to continually Inspire Ambition by fostering our love of service, scholarship, and leadership. We aim to create strong bonds of sisterhood by becoming women who value and savor lifelong friendships.

Here at Cal Poly, you will find AOII sisters are actively involved everywhere on
campus. Many of our sisters serve as WOW leaders, members of Greek Row, Resident Assistants, ASI Student Leaders, Academic Tutors, Club Sports members, and much more. In addition to our involvement in campus, our sisters participate in numerous philanthropic efforts. We are involved in campus wide sponsored service events as well as other Greek community’s philanthropy events. Our involvement is not limited to the Cal Poly campus; it extends to the San Luis Obispo and surrounding communities. Our largest philanthropy and the one closest to our hearts is The Arthritis Foundation.
Our weeks are filled with sisterhood events, educational opportunities, chapter events and philanthropies. There are so many ways to get involved even as a brand new member! The opportunity for leadership development and growth is an experience many of our sisters take to heart!

Friendship is a word that is frequently used in reference to Greek life. In Alpha Omicron Pi, we emphasize the importance of authenticity. Our differences become our assets. For where one girl is weak, another girl is strong, and in this way we have established a support system that inspires each of us to exceed every expectation we set for ourselves. Take a second to browse through our website and see what my sisters are all about. We can’t wait to meet you!
Summary: The object of the Fraternity shall be to encourage a spirit of Fraternity and love among its members; to stand at all times for character, dignity, scholarship, and college loyalty.

Name: Chinese Students' Association
Description: The Chinese Students’ Association (CSA) is a social cultural club of people who enjoy and appreciate Chinese culture, which also contains three performing groups: Lion Dance Team, Take Out Kids, and ShanWu. Take a look at our intro video here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hleG98Y4br0&t=1s
Summary: CSA is a social-cultural club that strives to bring people together through social events and celebrates Chinese culture, but most importantly our mission is to create an inclusive and friendly community.

Name: Christian Students
Summary: We are a group of believers who love the Lord and want to meet with others who pursue Him, regardless of their background.

Name: Club 34
Description: We are Club 34, Cal Poly's social art club. The name of our organization comes from the university number of Dexter building, which is the main location of the Art and Design department. We want to create a community space where students from all majors and disciplinary fields can come and create art. We want to allow students to explore different artistic media, learn about artists and events, and build a community with like-minded, creative people across the university. Club 34 welcomes everyone, and provides a safe space for learning, socializing, and creative expression.
Summary: Club 34 is Cal Poly's social art club. We aim to build a community of interdisciplinary creatives by hosting a handful of social events each quarter which may include student-run shows, craft nights, artist talks, and movie nights.

Name: Club Advisory Board
Summary: Representatives from different clubs and organizations at Cal Poly
CategoryNames: College of Agriculture, Food & Environmental Science

Name: Club Sports Council
Description:
The purpose of the Club Sports Council is to address common needs and concerns of all Club Sports teams at Cal Poly.

The Council is made up of one representative from each team. Attendance at Club Sports Council meetings is mandatory. 

The Council is led by a student Executive Board and their Advisor, the Sport Club Administrator. 

The Council convenes once a month. Meeting dates and times are set annually by the Sport Club Administrator. 

https://youtu.be/mNpcwoszjlI

More information is available on the Club Sports Office page. 

To view Club Sports Council meeting slides and recordings, please visit our homepage.
Summary: The Club Sports Council oversees Cal Poly's Club Sports program. We have 30 competitive member teams who all compete under their respective National Governing Bodies.

Name: Club Sports Office
Description:
About Club Sports

The mission of the Club Sports Program at Cal Poly is to provide a form of athletic and educational activity which is an integral part of collegiate life. It provides a common theme for a diversified student body, faculty, staff, and alumni to operate as partners both inside and outside the community. The Club Sports program at Cal Poly promotes the positive values of physical activity, learned skills, team development, and sportsmanship acquired through participation in competitions and organized activities.

 

Student-athletes are given a chance to compete against other sport clubs throughout the nation while enhancing their skill level and abilities in their respective sports. The goal of the Club Sports program is to develop a safe, fun, and competitive environment that provides athletes with opportunities to develop their character, experience a recreational and competitive athletic competition at a multitude of skill levels, develop a lifetime appreciation for sport and physical activity, and represent Cal Poly at competitions across the nation.

 

https://youtu.be/mNpcwoszjlI

 

Resources

Athletic Trainer Database
Summary: The Club Sports Office provides administrative support for the Club Sports Council and our 30 member teams.

Name: Club Tennis
Description:
Welcome to Cal Poly SLO Club Tennis!

 

We are a co-ed, club tennis organization. Founded in 2009, our team is known for being the perfect blend of competition and fun. Each year, our competitive team travels throughout California as well as across the United States to compete in 12+ large-scale tournaments against club tennis teams throughout the country. As a close-knit team, we are one big tennis family. Some of our best results include placing 1st at 2022 and 2023 Regionals, 2nd at 2024 Regionals, 10th at 2024 Nationals, 2nd at 2023 Nationals, 6th at 2022 Nationals, and consistently being one of the top teams in the country year after year. 

 

Club tennis is comprised of a competitive team and a general team. To join the competitive team, you must attend a 2-day tryout process. At tryouts, a $10 tryout fee is required. The first day of tryouts consists of common hitting drills and basic shot practice, while the second day consists of competitive match play. If you cannot make the tryout dates, we will also have alternate tryouts held at a different time after tryouts. Outside of tryouts, alternate tryouts, and extenuating circumstances, there will be no other opportunities to join the competitive team. Players on the competitive team will pay $225 in dues for the year up-front or $90 per quarter.

 

Competitive team tryouts will be held on October 4 and 5, 2025 at the Cal Poly Tennis Courts. On both days, men will tryout from 9-11AM and women will tryout from 12-2PM. To sign up for Competitive Team tryouts and get more info, Click Here!

 

Alternate competitive team tryouts are only reserved for players who are unable to attend the official tryout dates. If you have an unavoidable conflict (ie. Sorority/Fraternity Rush, injury, study abroad, etc.) and absolutely cannot attend tryouts, please email us at cptennisclub@gmail.com by October 3rd. Alternate tryout dates will only be considered in exceptional circumstances. 

 

General team is no-cut and is welcoming to players of all skill levels. There will be multiple events and team bonding activities held throughout the year. Players interested in joining the general team can do so at any point in the year as there is no try-out process. General team members will pay $40 for the year up-front or $17 per quarter (we will have change for cash!). To sign up for General Team, Click Here!

 

See answers to our most commonly asked questions here!

 

Click here to donate to our club! 

 

Our Club Tennis families, supporters, and alumni! If you would like to receive regular emails containing our club tournament results, upcoming events, and all club related news, Subscribe to Our Newsletter Here!

 

Follow us on Instagram (@cpclubtennis), TikTok (@calpolyclubtennis), or email us (cptennisclub@gmail.com)!
Summary: Club Tennis is a co-ed team whose goal is to allow players of all skill levels to continue their tennis careers at Cal Poly, and to develop a tight-knit group in the process. Our competitive team travels monthly to compete with teams across the nation.

Name: Clubs & Organizations Office
Description:
Clubs and organizations at Cal Poly provide opportunities that incorporate instruction, scholarship, and service in a Learn by Doing environment. Students, staff, and faculty partner to apply theory to practice by competing in national competitions, addressing global issues, and serving the community at large. The Clubs & Organizations' hands-on approach develops leadership skills, enhances social growth, and complements the academic curriculum.

 

Club Forms

Visit the Forms tab to find the following forms:

- Bylaw Builder

- Organization Change Form (for Presidents/Primary Contacts only)

- Request a Cal Poly Email Address (for Presidents/Primary Contacts only)

 

Forms hosted by other departments:

Fundraising Event Approval (only required for events that hope to raise $5000 or more)

 

Scroll down to the Documents sections to download resources available to clubs.

 

New Student Organizations

For information on how to start a new student organization, visit the Start a Club page.
Summary: The Clubs & Organizations Office officially recognizes student clubs and organizations. We partner with ASI Club Services in administering club services and support.

Name: CodeBox
Description:
A club for builders, dreamers, and doers. CodeBox helps students turn project ideas into reality by connecting them with teammates, project leads, and tech leads. Whether you're into AI, web dev, hardware, or something totally new—if it’s fun and you’re passionate, this is your space.

Apply to join a project team or contribute to our club-wide open-source project. All project team members, whether individual teams or the general club project, are part of CodeBox, with every project housed under the club to foster a shared sense of ownership, community, and collaboration.

Build cool things. Gain real experience. Grow together.
Summary: A club for builders and doers. CodeBox helps students bring project ideas to life by connecting them with teams, project leads, and tech leads. Whether it’s AI, web, or something totally new—if it’s fun and you’re passionate, this is your place.

Name: College Corps Service Opportunities
Description:
College Corps fellows serve 450 hours throughout the academic year within a primary host site. The events listed below will be a list of College Corps hosted events for our fellows and supplemental service opportunities. Supplemental Service is the opportunity to serve outside of one's host site on a as-need basis within the three focus areas of climate action, K-12 education, and food insecurity. Supplemental service should never replace or hinder the service a fellow completes at their primary host site. The opportunities listed below are pre-approved supplemental service opportunities for our College Corps fellows. 

Interested in becoming a fellow? Check out our website to learn more about what our amazing fellows do!
Summary: Are you a College Corps fellow interested in doing some service outside of your primary host site? You're in the right place! Check out some fun supplemental service opportunities below.

Name: College of Agriculture, Food, and Environmental Sciences Ambassadors
Description: CAFES Ambassadors is a college-wide student organization who serve as the leadership and public relations team for the College of Agriculture, Food and Environmental Sciences (CAFES). The 2025-26 academic year will be the 37th year the organization has worked to promote the college to prospective students, alumni, industry and government partners, donors and other stakeholders. CAFES Ambassadors have provided a positive influence on the quantity as well as the quality of applicants admitted to CAFES.
Summary: CAFES Ambassadors is a college-wide student organization who serve as the leadership and public relations team for the College of Agriculture, Food and Environmental Sciences (CAFES).
CategoryNames: College of Agriculture, Food & Environmental Science

Name: College of Agriculture, Food, and Environmental Sciences Student Council
Description: Serves as the communication line between the student organizations within the College of Agriculture, Food and Environmental Sciences and the Associated Students, Incorporated (ASI). This council promotes cooperation and coordination among the student organizations through discussion of mutual interests, activities, and new ideas from each student organization.
Summary: College of Agriculture Food and Environmental Sciences has one representative from each club to come together for a meeting every Tuesday to talk about different events going on in our college.
CategoryNames: College of Agriculture, Food & Environmental Science

Name: College of Engineering Ambassadors
Summary: The CENG Ambassadors are an enthusiastic and knowledgeable team of students who actively represent the College of Engineering through campus tours and public relations roles at request.

Name: College of Liberal Arts Ambassadors
Description: The CLA Student Ambassador Program is a dynamic, enthusiastic and knowledgeable team of students who actively represent the CLA in visible public relations roles. Student ambassadors participate in events such as Open House, advisory councils, campus tours, and alumni events. Student Ambassadors represent the CLA, its programs and students to the Cal Poly community, prospective students, supporters and alumni.
Summary: CLA Ambassadors represent the College of Liberal Arts to prospective, current, and past students.

Name: College of Science and Mathematics Ambassadors
Description:
The Cal Poly College of Science and Mathematics Ambassadors is a group of dedicated students who are eager to be involved in Bailey College by giving tours to prospective students, and organize/participate in diversity and outreach events.

If you are interested in becoming an ambassador, recruitment occurs in the Fall quarter each year! Please contact bailey-ambassadors@calpoly.edu with any questions you have about the club or how to become an ambassador.
Summary: The Cal Poly College of Science and Mathematics Ambassadors is a group of dedicated students who are eager to be involved in COSAM by giving tours to prospective students, and organize/participate in diversity and outreach events.

Name: Color Coded
Description:
We celebrate diversity, respect, and uniqueness. Our organization hosts career-readiness workshops, diversity round tables, technical interview seminars, and social networking opportunities among many others.

The mission of Color Coded is to support the academic and professional success of underrepresented minority groups in tech, with an emphasis on supporting students who identify as Black, Latinx, and/or Native American at the California Polytechnic State University, San Luis Obispo.
Summary: Founded in 2018, "Color Coded: Diversity in Tech" is a student-led organization aiming to promote the professional and academic success of underrepresented students in the technology industry.

Name: Commencement Office
Summary: The Commencement Office provides graduates and their guests with a memorable and meaningful graduation experience that symbolizes the culmination of their academic achievements.

Name: Communication Studies Club
Summary: Cal Poly COMS Club is a dynamic organization designed for students who are interested in understanding the communication field with a focus on academic, professional, and social experiences.

Name: Comparative Ethnic Studies Student Association
Description: • Actively implementing the critical study of interlocking systems and structures of oppression by supporting students at an interpersonal level, bringing the essence of the field of Comparative Ethnic Studies to a broader audience, and disseminating information in an accessible and relevant manner.
Summary: Comparative Ethnic Studies Student Association's purpose is to provide a place to supplement the educational and networking experiences of students with an interest in Comparative Ethnic Studies.

Name: Computer Architecture Research Project at Cal Poly
Description: The Computer Architecture Research Project (CARP) at Cal Poly is a student-led organization that brings together students interested in understanding and creating the hardware that powers modern computing. CARP provides a collaborative environment where members can learn through experience, designing processors, developing ASICs, and contributing to open-source silicon projects. The group emphasizes mentorship, education, and technical growth, helping students bridge the gap between theory and real-world engineering through hands-on research and design in computer architecture.
Summary: The Computer Architecture Research Project (CARP) at Cal Poly is a student-led community focused on education, mentorship, research, and open-source chip design. Our goal is to provide students with hands-on opportunities to explore computer architecture

Name: Computer Science and Artificial Intelligence
Description:
CS+AI is a computer science club where we work together to build data science-driven projects and conduct research in machine learning approaches. We educate members how to effectively work on a software team and provide a platform for them to explore cutting-edge technology. Over the years, we have built various voice assistants, chatbots, computer vision projects and AR software. Members have worked on general machine learning, natural language processing, hardware design, database architecture, data mining and frontend development. The diversity of skill sets present in the club allows all of us to expand our knowledge in unexpected ways.

Through workshops and discussions, we elevate the abilities of everyone in the club and prepare members to apply data science principles to their careers. Members also benefit from guest lecturers, who share their industry experience with us and occasionally offer job openings. In the past, we have hosted speakers from Google, Meta, Amazon, and Intel. But most importantly, CSAI is a safe place to make friends and explore the field of Computer Science as a community. 

Join our Discord server to stay in touch: https://discord.gg/SxqcmnvdQd
Summary: CSAI brings students together to tackle meaningful problems using artificial intelligence.

Name: Computing Club Collaborative
Summary: Leaders from computing organizations on campus come together to create immersive events for Cal Poly students!

Name: CORE
Description:
Core is a pre-WOW program rooted in proactively connecting underrepresented students to the resources, community, and connections that will kickstart their leadership journey at Cal Poly instilling confidence in their ability to navigate their Week of Welcome experience with pride. 

Students will participate in a series of workshops that will foster a sense of community, introduce students to different leadership opportunities, and engage students with sources of support that will help students thrive as a new Mustang.

If you have any questions, please email the program at CORE@calpoly.edu
Summary: Core is a pre-WOW program rooted in proactively connecting underrepresented students to the resources, community, and connections that will kickstart their leadership journey at Cal Poly instilling confidence in their ability to navigate their WoW.

Name: Country Line Dancing Club
Description:
The Cal Poly Country Line Dancing Club is a student run social and dance club designed to teach others all they need to learn about country line dancing. From partner patterns to the most basic line dances, we ensure that our members and partners have everything they need to know before hitting the dance floor. Check out our website: https://cldccalpoly.wixsite.com/cldccalpoly to learn more about what our club has to offer!

If you are interested in joining the organization, attend a Friday Night Workshop where you can try out a dance lesson and purchase a membership!
Summary: The Country Line Dancing Club provides engaging, interactive line and partner dancing instruction to students and offers a safe environment for members to learn everything they need to know about country line dancing.

Name: CP Drag Club
Summary: Cal Poly Drag Club was founded as a way to give on campus queer artists and enthusiasts a way to explore and embrace themselves.

Name: Cru
Description:
A community at Cal Poly focused on connecting fellow students to Jesus, seeing lives changed by Jesus and community, and equipping students to live with purpose as part of God’s work of renewal. Take a look at our main instagram, @crucalpolyslo, or stay updated on our slack channel, cru-cal-poly-slo.slack.com!

 

We also have groups that focus on the agriculture community and greek life. If you are interested in either of those, you can find their instagrams at @branded_cpslo and @cpslogreekrow. We can't wait to connect with you!
Summary: Cru Central Coast is a part of Cru, an interdenominational, worldwide Christian ministry with the goal of giving every student the opportunity to hear and respond to the Good News of Jesus Christ.

Name: Dean of Students
Description:
The Office of the Dean of Students is committed to creating a welcoming, inclusive university campus for you. We provide students with assistance in navigating Cal Poly and connecting them with appropriate resources. Overall, we strive to provide resources and spaces for everyone to connect to a community and be supported throughout their college experience. 

Mission

The Office of the Dean of Students creates opportunities that increase access, allow for exploration of advocacy and privilege, and promote a welcoming campus climate. We foster individual strengths, self-exploration, community building and collaboration; encourage personal and academic success through self-advocacy, leadership and accountability; and equip the Cal Poly community with tools to become lifelong learners and global citizens. 

Vision

Provide students the support and skills to thrive in a diverse and changing world. 

Values

Advocacy - Serve as an advocate for students to address their needs and facilitate problem-solving and conflict resolution.

Community - Partner with the campus community to create a sense of belonging and trust.

Integrity - Lead by example and align our practice with our core values and the ethical principles of our profession.

Social Justice - Actively challenge unjust practices and policies and promote dialogue and interaction about issues related to diversity, inclusion and social justice through education.

Student Success - Anticipate and respond to student needs by providing exceptional services that enhance and support student success.

The Office of the Dean of Students includes Student, Support, Success and Retention and Office of Student Rights & Responsibilities.

 

Office of the Dean of Students

Office of Student Rights & Responsibilities

Student Support, Success & Retention
Summary: The Office of the Dean of Students is committed to creating a welcoming, inclusive university campus for you. We provide students with assistance in navigating Cal Poly and connecting them with appropriate resources.

Name: Delight Ministries at Cal Poly
Description: We are a women's Christian club that meets every Monday night from 8:00PM-9:15 PM. We typically go through a chapter in our Delight book each week and we'd love to have you! We also plan fun community and serve events that you won't want to miss! Follow us on Instagram @delight_centralcoast for more info!
Summary: Delight is a club inviting college women on the central coast into Christ-centered community that fosters vulnerability and transforms stories.

Name: Delta Chi
Description:
Delta Chi is a campus-affiliated Greek Fraternity. We strive to benefit the lives and characters of each and every one of our members. We foster a unique brotherhood centered around loyalty, compassion, & gentlemanly conduct. The four pillars of Delta Chi are promoting friendship, developing character, advancing justice and assisting in the acquisition of a sound education. 

Our Website: cpdeltachi.com

Instagram: instagram.com/cpdeltachi/
Summary: Delta Chi is a campus-affiliated Greek Fraternity. We strive to benefit the lives and characters of each and every one of our members. We foster a unique brotherhood centered around loyalty, compassion, & gentlemanly conduct.

Name: Delta Sigma Phi - Epsilon Rho Chapter
Description:
Delta Sigma Phi's mission is "Building Better Men". The "Better Man" is defined as a man of courage, a man of action, and a man of excellence. Members of Delta Sigma Phi value culture, harmony, and friendship.

DSP was founded in 1899 at the City College of New York and now has over 100 active chapters nationwide. We have a vast network of supportive and involved Cal Poly alumni as well as brotherhood connections all around the country.
Summary: Delta Sigma Phi's mission is "Building Better Men". The "Better Man" is defined as a man of courage, a man of action, and a man of excellence. Members of Delta Sigma Phi value culture, harmony, and friendship.

Name: Delta Sigma Pi Kappa Mu Chapter
Summary: Delta Sigma Pi is a professional fraternity organized to foster the study of business in universities and promote closer affiliation between the commercial world and students of commerce.

Name: Delta Upsilon
Description: The Delta Upsilon chapter at Cal Poly strives to build better men while also cultivating an environment that promotes philanthropic and good mannered action. Since our founding we have continued to pursue these ideals to the fullest and be a positive light to the entirety of Cal Poly and San Luis Obispo.
Summary: Cal Poly affiliated fraternity chapter that strives to bring philanthropy and volunteer service to the Cal Poly campus and surrounding SLO community

Name: Design Lab
Description: Design Lab provides a space for designers and professionals to connect, collaborate on projects, and learn more about each other and the industry. Our members are passionate about all things design-related, including graphic design, typography, UX/UI, interaction design, and more. Join us for events such as creative workshops, studio tours, and talks with speakers from throughout the industry. We aim to empower designers through mentorship, community, and connection!
Summary: Design Lab provides a space for designers and professionals to connect, collaborate on projects, and learn more about each other and the industry.

Name: Design Village
Description:
Winner of the 2022 Leadership in Action Award // LEAD Awards

The Design Village Organization was founded in 1975 at the California Polytechnic University of San Luis Obispo. Since then, our organization has grown in national prominence, and as a result, we have sponsored annual events in collaboration with The College of Architecture & Environmental Design, in which architecture students across California compete in a design-build competition by creating a physical structure to be occupied throughout the course of the competition weekend.

Every year, Design Village reveals a concept inspired by a specific design philosophy, after which competitors are challenged to design and build a physical structure related to the concept. The criteria for evaluation are INNOVATION, AESTHETICS, FUNCTIONALITY, DURABILITY, and ECOLOGICAL COMPATIBILITY.  To ensure a team's structure adheres to Design Village's Official Competition Rules, contestants must occupy their structures for the duration of the competition weekend.
Summary: Design Village is a student-run organization that hosts annual design-build competitions under the direct sponsorship of Cal Poly's CAED. Competitors across the country compete alongside Cal Poly students to claim winner of the year's theme.

Name: Disability Resource Center
Description:
The Disability Resource Center provides information and support services to Cal Poly students with permanent and temporary disabilities.

 

Once incoming students have provided current disability verification to the DRC office, they will be scheduled for an individual intake appointment with a DRC Access Specialist. During this appointment, appropriate support services will be discussed and authorized, based on the current functional limitations that may result from the disability. 

 

Policies for the provision of support services are available in writing and may be referenced from this site.

 

Students can review their accommodation plan and make alternative media, notetaking, and test requests online by logging into the My Cal Poly Portal and clicking on the Student Accommodations link. 

 

For more information, visit the DRC Online Portal webpage.

 

Disability Documentation Forms (students who prefer not to use our form should ensure that the documentation they submit is on letterhead, signed, addresses symptoms, functional limitations along with severity, and the expected duration of the disability)
 
5-Minute Overview of DRC Services
 

How to Request Services
Summary: The Disability Resource Center (DRC) cultivates an accessible and inclusive community where students with permanent and temporary disabilities have an equal opportunity to participate in all aspects of campus life.

Name: Diversity & Inclusion
Description:
Diversity & Inclusion is a collective of campus resource centers that support and empower students experiencing marginalization, through intersectional advocacy and cultural connections to build a more just and equitable Cal Poly community.

 

This organization focuses specifically on Diversity & Inclusion events that are distinct from those sponsored by the Student Diversity Advisory Board (SDAB).

 

Student Diversity & Belonging is comprised of the following campus community centers organized into two cluster areas:

Gender & Sexuality

  • Gender Equity Center
  • LGBTQ Campus Life (PRIDE)
  • Men & Masculinities

Race & Ethnicity

  • Black Academic Excellence Center
  • Dream Center
  • Multicultural Center
Summary: Diversity & Inclusion is a collective of campus resource centers that support and empower students experiencing marginalization, through intersectional advocacy and cultural connections to build a more just and equitable Cal Poly community.

Name: Dragon Boating Outreach Club
Description:
The Central Coast Adventurers are a dragon boating team in Morro Bay. The club helps students join and access the team, plans races and events, and promotes outreach. A beginner friendly team, we welcome new faces and the chance to grow our community. Members and guests will have the opportunity to see marine wildlife (otters!) while exercising and learning about the sport with our team. 

To sign up for the Adventurers Dragon Boat Team view our sign up info under the documents section!
Summary: We are a Cal Poly club affiliated with the Central Coast Adventurers Dragon Boat team in which students have the opportunity to paddle in Morro Bay in a fun and supportive environment. We provide a chance to see wildlife, build community, and exercise!

Name: Dream Center
Description:
Empowering undocumented and DACA students, we are committed to creating access for these students to navigate higher education. The Dream Center additionally serves students from mixed status families and allies with support, education and community. We advocate for the academic, professional, and personal development and success for all students that connect with the Dream Center. The center facilitates the CSU’s immigration legal services program in partnership with the organization, Immigration Legal Defense. Students can make appointments with this resource using the following link. 

The Dream Center, through programming and dialogues such as Dream Circles, provides their students with opportunities to understand their own identities and intersectionality with their status. The Dream Center staff also provides presentations, workshops and trainings for the larger campus community (ie: allies) to unlearn and deconstruct the racialized ideology of “who” is viewed as undocumented or “who” belongs to this community, and we aim to uplift all diasporas and identities of this group.  

Through the efforts of ensuring our students are well-resourced, advocated for, and have provisions to meet their basic needs, we also center radical joy through celebrations, social events and other programs that are designed to remind us that we are allowed to laugh amid adversity.  

 

Location: 

yakʔitʸutʸu, Building 172, Room H1-46

 

Operating Hours: 

Monday – Friday 9:00 AM – 5:00 PM 

 

Center Center Offerings: 

We connect students with CSU-wide free Immigrant legal services, offer peer-to-peer Undocu-Ally presentations, and our Center has computers, printing, serves as a hangout space, study space, napping space, food cabinet, snacks, social events, programming, and more. 

 

CSU-wide Partnership with Immigration Legal Defense: https://www.ild.org/csu-immigration-legal-services-project 


Throughout the year we host many events, check the feed below to register for our upcoming events. Below are the descriptions of past events: 

Social Butterflies: 
A series of social events to help build community and relieve stress during the quarter. 

Undocu-week: 
A week filled with events centered on and celebrating the undocumented community 

Mental Health Check-Ins : 
Monthly drop-ins with an undocu-ally trained member of Cal Poly’s Health and Wellbeing services in the Dream Center. 

Undocu-talks: 
Monthly one-on-one, confidential virtual drop-ins with an undocu ally trained member of Cal Poly’s Health and Wellbeing services. 

Dream Circle:  
A processing and dialogue space centering issues and topics brought up by our Dream Center student community. 

IG: @calpoly_dream
Summary: Providing holistic support and resources to undocu/DACA students, members of mixed status families, and allies through empowering and educational programming, community building, and campus referrals. Register for this quarter’s events in our profile

Name: Eastern European and Central Asian Student Association
Summary: A social space for students to connect to Eastern European culture, Central Asian culture, and each other through language, music, cuisine, and volunteering.

Name: Eco Reps
Description:
Eco Reps is a group of students committed to creating a culture of environmental stewardship on campus at Cal Poly. Managed by the Green Campus Team within Facilities, Eco-Reps exemplify the "learn by doing" motto and play a direct role in Cal Poly's advancement to a fully sustainable future. Our club meetings are open to anyone looking meet other green-minded people while furthering your foundational knowledge of sustainability! We often hear from guest speakers, learn about campus initiatives, and volunteer in environmental work like tree planting or litter cleanups.

The best way to stay engaged with Eco Reps is by following us on Instagram @calpolyecoreps
Summary: Eco Reps are committed to creating a culture of environmental stewardship on campus at Cal Poly. Eco Reps exemplify the motto 'Growing Greener Minds' and plays a direct role in Cal Poly's advancement for sustainability.

Name: Educational Opportunity Program (EOP)
Description: The primary goals of the Educational Opportunity Program (EOP) are to improve the access, retention and graduation of students who have been historically, economically and/or educationally disadvantaged. The core of our program services are built upon a student-centered model which encourages college success, community building, and empowerment.
Summary: Provides admission, academic and financial support services to historically underserved students throughout California.

Name: EIM Club
Description:
• Network with your fellow EIM students at Social events 
  • Gain valuable career insights from Guest Speakers 
  • Gain inspiration from Alumni
  • Other Resources & Opportunities
  • Annual Auction & Dinner

EXPERIENCE INDUSTRY MANAGEMENT CLUB

Follow our Instagram @EIMCLUB for updates! 

Experience Industry Management Club strives to provide both educational and social opportunities for students. We have career networking opportunities with professional guest speakers, socials to meet others in the major and minor, and volunteer opportunities! We have biweekly meetings with snacks, speakers, and lots of fun! Are you interested in event planning, sports and recreation management, or tourism, hospitality, and destination management? Experience Industry Management Club is the place for you!
Summary: The EIM Club is a student organization that has a primary focus to serve students, whether majors or not, interested in recreation, parks, and tourism administration (RPTA). We provide opportunities in networking, jobs, and local business insights.
CategoryNames: College of Agriculture, Food & Environmental Science

Name: End Alzheimer's
Summary: End Alzheimer's is looking to expand the Alzheimer's Association's outreach to the Cal Poly campus. We will educate students through a variety of presentations and guest speakers, as well as provide support to those affected by the disease.

Name: Engineering Student Council
Description: Engineering Student Council (ESC) serves as a medium for communication between engineering students, the College of Engineering, and the University in order to facilitate conversation and allow students to voice their opinions. We strive to enhance the student experience within the College by providing cohesion and cooperation between the diverse student organizations and clubs within the College of Engineering. Finally, ESC aspires to provide access to opportunities for personal growth and experience pertaining to education and post-educational goals.  Engineering Student Council strives to bring a voice to all members in the College of Engineering, fostering communication between the faculty and student body. Through student-led initiatives, we continuously cultivate a more inclusive and diverse community, committed to equity, social, and environmental justice. on our campus. This is, and will be, an ongoing endeavor.
Summary: The Engineering Student Council serves to bridge the communication gap between engineering students, the College of Engineering, and the University, and provides cohesion and cooperation between the diverse student organizations and clubs within CENG.

Name: Engineers for Global Cultural Awareness
Description: Engineers for Global Awareness is a space for engineers to learn more about the different engineering practices and needs worldwide, and understanding our role to address these needs feasibly.
Summary: Engineers for Global Awareness is a space for engineers to learn more about the different engineering practices worldwide.

Name: Environmental Sciences Club
Description: ESC serves to introduce students who are interested in Environmental Science to potential career paths, community service organizations, and recreational activities related to environmental science and natural resources.
Summary: ESC serves to introduce students who are interested in Environmental Science to potential career paths, community service organizations, and recreational activities related to environmental science and natural resources.
CategoryNames: College of Agriculture, Food & Environmental Science

Name: Epic Movement
Description: Epic Movement is an Asian American Christian Fellowship that seeks to become apart of God's redemptive mission to share the Gospel Worldwide. We seek to attain this by winning students over for Christ, building them up through community, and sending them out to share the Gospel. We welcome, embrace, and recognize people from all backgrounds as we are all a part of Christ's family. We are a community that gathers together on a weekly basis to build friendships and worship the Lord. Click this link to discover more! https://youtu.be/zqKO4jUEyQk
Summary: Epic is an Asian American Christian movement that is focused on bringing the love of Jesus Christ to students at Cal Poly. We seek to become apart of God's redemptive mission to share the Gospel world-wide.

Name: Epsilon Chi Chapter of Alpha Phi International Fraternity Incorporated
Description:
Alpha Phi Fraternity was founded in 1872 by ten forward thinking women at Syracuse University, and is now one of the oldest and largest women's fraternities in North America. This individual chapter at Cal Poly was founded at Cal Poly back in 1975, and we are now made up of 280 strong, empowering, and strong women who are dedicated to the preservation and longevity of the principles of Alpha Phi. Our keystone is friendship – warm, simple and sincere.

 

This organization assists college women in making informed choices to reach their highest potential. Alpha Phi enhances and promotes each member's development and learning by focusing on sisterhood, service, scholarship, leadership, loyalty and character development. Our sisters all share a commitment to excellence and a strong desire to help one another as well as their communities. 

 

To learn more about the great legacy of Alpha Phi, check out our chapter’s website:https://calpolyalphaphi.wixsite.com/website as well as International’s website: www.alphaphi.org
Summary: Alpha Phi is a sisterhood of outstanding women supporting one another in lifelong achievement. The sisterhood of Alpha Phi stretches from coast to coast through 164 collegiate campuses and more than 200,000 members.

Name: Epsilon Omega Chapter of Alpha Chi Omega
Description:
Welcome to the Epsilon Omega Chapter of Alpha Chi Omega at Cal Poly, San Luis Obispo. Thank you for taking the time to visit our website and learn more about our chapter! Alpha Chi Omega was founded to provide a basis of mutual helpfulness and congenial fellowship. The purpose of Alpha Chi Omega was to provide the advancement of the intellectual, social, and moral culture of its members. 

Our chapter is deeply dedicated to our philanthropy: the fight against domestic violence and sexual assault. The Alpha Chi Omega Foundation supports educational programs for victims of domestic violence as well as hands-on support at the local community level where personal involvement can make a difference. Grants go to various agencies across the nation providing services to victims as well as providing development and implementation of educational programs for members.​ 

Our chapter works directly with the San Luis Obispo Women's Shelter and Lumina Alliance. They work to provide a safe place for women and children to get back on their feet after experiencing domestic violence or an unhealthy relationship. Learn more below about the quarterly and annual events we organize to raise money, awareness, and support for this important cause.
Summary: Alpha Chi Omega was founded to provide a basis of mutual helpfulness and of congenial fellowship. The purpose of Alpha Chi Omega was to provide the advancement of the intellectual, social and moral culture of its members.

Name: Esports Council
Description: This Organization is the official voice of the many different esports and gaming clubs that exist on campus in order to promote and champion the needs, interests, and activities of the students who engage with the gaming community at Cal Poly.
Summary: This Organization is the official voice of the many different esports and gaming clubs that exist on campus in order to promote and champion the needs, interests, and activities of the students who engage with the gaming community at Cal Poly.

Name: Eta Kappa Nu
Description:
About Us

Eta Kappa Nu is the IEEE affiliated Engineering Honor Society for Electrical Engineering, Computer Engineering, and Computer Science majors. Eta Kappa Nu promotes excellence in profession and in education through an emphasis on scholarship, character, and attitude. 

 

Membership

Membership in Eta Kappa Nu is by invitation only. Applications are not accepted.
Summary: Electrical and Computer Engineering Honor Society

Name: Eta Septaton Chapter Phi Sigma Kappa
Description: Phi Sigma Kappa is a lifelong brotherhood dedicated to the betterment of the individual, the university community, and our world, by giving its members opportunities to develop leadership skills, participate in service to others, achieve academic excellence, experience cultural diversity and practice personal integrity.
Summary: The Eta Septaton Chapter of Phi Sigma Kappa is a group of brothers that promotes our three pillars of brotherhood, scholarship, and character in each of our lives.

Name: Eta-Delta Chapter of Sigma Pi Fraternity
Description: Sigma Pi is a social Fraternity who's members strive for excellence by living our core values to promote fellowship, develop character and leadership, advance heightened moral awareness, enable academic achievement, and inspire service.
Summary: Eta Delta Chapter of Sigma Pi Fraternity, International

Name: Fashion, Innovation, Trendsetting, and Styling Club
Summary:
A community for students who are interested in the realm of fashion and learning skills in garment construction, styling, design, modeling, and fashion photography, while integrating the values of sustainable fashion. 

Formerly known as FAST

Name: Financial Management Association
Description: This organization brings members of the finance concentration together with weekly speaker meetings and events.

Name: Fraternity & Sorority Life
Description:
The Fraternity & Sorority community here at Cal Poly is home to 36 social Fraternity & Sorority organizations comprised of over 3500 students. Every organization is affiliated with one of the 3 governing councils: Panhellenic Association (PHA), United Sorority & Fraternity Council (USFC) and the Interfraternity Council (IFC).

 

Our community sets high standards for its members and focuses on our 6 pillars of excellence: Scholarship & Learning, Leadership & Values, Community Service & Philanthropy, Safety & Risk Management, Unity & Belonging, and Diversity & Inclusion.

Every year the members of our community work together to hold each other accountable to these pillars by hosting philanthropic events, community service initiatives, high academic standards, as well as providing opportunities to give members a home away from home at Cal Poly through brotherhood and sisterhood retreats, Greek Week or partnering with other clubs and organizations to build a stronger network.

 

Last year, our community completed 48,000 community service hours and raised $424,361 for National and local causes! Additionally, our community hosted over 50 educational programs as well as had 30% of members on the Dean’s List for academics and has prioritized even greater efforts to provide academic support.

 

Once you join a fraternity or sorority, you will have the opportunity to join academic honors societies and utilize all of the resources provided to these organizations.

Name: French Language Club
Description:
We are a welcoming community for anyone who wants to practice their French whether you are a native speaker or a novice! We have French cultural activities, movie nights, and game nights! If you are interested in coming to our weekly meetings, email tgudkov@calpoly.edu OR join the GroupMe at: 

https://groupme.com/join_group/85554600/e1CvxP6C
Summary: The French Language Club is a group dedicated to speaking and practicing speaking French. All skill levels are welcome. We do social events, like French-themed soirées, but mainly practice conversational french.

Name: Furries at Cal Poly
Description:
Furries at Cal Poly is an art-based social club that strives to create a welcoming space for furries at Cal Poly.

What is a furry?

Furries are people who are interested in anthropomorphic animal characters. From the protagonists of your favorite nostalgic cartoons to our own unique fursonas, we come together to share and appreciate art based on these colorful characters.

While fursuits (anthro animal costumes) are the most recognizable parts of our fandom, you don't need to have a fursuit to be a furry.
Summary: Join an inclusive and passionate community of furries on campus! We organize art workshops, furmeets, convention info sessions, and outreach for everything anthro.

Name: Future Math Educators
Description: The primary goal of the club is increasing communication, fostering social connections, and the creation and upkeep of a community among students, faculty, and staff at Cal Poly interested in the study of the teaching of mathematics.
Summary: The primary goal of the club is increasing communication, fostering social connections, and the creation and upkeep of a community among students, faculty, and staff at Cal Poly interested in the study of the teaching of mathematics.

Name: Future Opportunities through Research, Growth, and Entrepreneurship
Description: The purpose of FORGE is to empower students to innovate, brainstorm, lead, and solve real-world problems through STEM and entrepreneurship. We aim to provide the tools and community necessary for students with big ideas to connect with like-minded individuals, think critically, and implement their ideas realistically and creatively. We emphasize the belief that “The world was created by people no smarter than you,” challenging the notion that extensive experience is required to start something impactful. Our club brings together people from diverse technical backgrounds to create businesses that make a real difference. We embody the “learn by doing” model, encouraging members to tackle the world’s most complex problems, learn from failure, and have fun while making a meaningful impact.
Summary: FORGE empowers students to innovate, lead, and solve real problems through STEM and entrepreneurship. We provide tools and a community for big ideas, fostering critical thinking, collaboration, and creativity.encouraging action, failure, and real impact.

Name: Gamma Phi Beta, Delta Theta Chapter
Description:
Gamma Phi Beta is a sorority committed to building confident women of character who celebrate sisterhood and make a difference in the world around us. The Delta Theta Chapter at Cal Poly, San Luis Obispo is composed of 280 exceptional members. Gamma Phi's mission is to inspire the highest type of womanhood, through personal development, sisterhood, networking, and more.

Our members strive to live through our four core values: love, labor, learning, and loyalty. We promote lifelong commitment, intellectual and personal growth, and service to humanity. These values are reflected through our philanthropic efforts.

Gamma Phi Beta strives to make a difference in the world around us by building strong girls and even stronger women. On a national level, we raise money for Girls on the Run. Locally, our chapter focuses on mental health awareness and suicide prevention. The Delta Theta Chapter strives to reduce the stigma around mental health and provide resources for our members and the SLO community. We support the Transitions Mental Health Association and the Woods Humane Society through this focus.

We encourage our members to seek out leadership opportunities. Many of the women in our chapter are actively involved in organizations such as Poly Reps, Greek Row, and the Associated Students Inc., to name a few. In an organization bound by many shared values, the interests and strengths of individual members are what make our chapter unique.
Summary: Panhellenic Sorority

Name: Gender Equity Center (GEC)
Description:
The Gender Equity Center (GEC) is a resource center designed to empower feminine, transgender, womxn-of-center, non-binary, gender-expansive students and their supporters. The GEC envisions a society liberated from the oppressive constraints of the gender binary and cis-hetero-patriarchy, where all genders are honored, validated, and celebrated. Through social justice-based education, intersectional advocacy, and expansive programming, we invite the Cal Poly campus community to cultivate a brave space where we can learn and grow. 

 

Location: 

Room 217I University Union (065-217I). Enter the suite from the doors behind the center for leadership and it’s the last room on the left of the hallway. See the map below for details. 

Operating Hours: 

Monday – Friday 9:00am-5:00pm.  

Space open to students: 

The center is open to students during normal university union operating hours regardless of whether staff are present. 

Center Space Offerings: 

Sexual health supplies, menstrual health supplies, gender affirming campus resources, rest area, workspace, printing, crafting, library and connections to health and well-being services. 

We host numerous events throughout the year, check the feed below to register for our upcoming events. Below are the descriptions of past quarterly and signature programs: 

 

Our programming consists of quarterly and signature events. 

GEMS (Gender, Experiences, Monologues, and Stories): GEMS is a student-created production at the intersection of social justice and theatre featuring a zine, art gallery, and performance in April. GEMS features stories of misogyny-affected people, the gender nonconforming experience, and experiences of marginalization through gender in body, mind, and/or spirit, whether past, present, future, and/or fluid. The stories featured in GEMS are written and submitted by Cal Poly and SLO community members, and we encourage folks to apply during Fall! 

Palentines: Join us in February to celebrate love and intimacy across our various kinds of healthy relationships.  

Womxn’s History Month: Typically held during early March, the GEC coordinates numerous programs to celebrate femininity and womxn’s history, including the State of Womxn dialogue event. 

Womxn of Color (WOC) Mixer: Occurring during Fall Quarter, WOC explores femininity and intersectionality, aiming to cultivate a network among womxn of color students to professional, educational and community building opportunities.

Gender Equity training: Gender Equity training is an opt-in program during the Winter and Spring quarters. Students learn about gender identity, expression and advocacy through an intersectional lens. 

Rotating affinity spaces: These can change every year and/or quarter. They can look like discursive affinity spaces, peer support spaces, book clubs, and more!

 

To stay up to date on the latest center news and programs, we recommend following our Cal Poly Now and center Instagram. 

IG: @calpoly_gec
Summary: Founded by students the Gender Equity Center empowers feminine, transgender, womxn-of-center, other gender-expansive students, and their supporters through expansive and inclusive programing. Register for this quarter’s events in our profile.

Name: Gender-Inclusive Gaming
Description:
Gender-Inclusive Gaming is a community that supports minorities who are interested in gaming as a leisure activity! We have a community of people in our club Discord (https://discord.gg/EsrMVeCQj8). Our club is a hybrid entity that boasts both Discord and in person meetings!

 

GIG has two Discords: a larger one that works to create a safe space to connect gamers across campus, and a smaller one with activity restrictions that aims to foster social connection. We host Game Nights and PowerPoint Nights in meetings where we allow individuals to share their personal interests! We welcome all identities, including neurodivergent, non-cis and queer individuals. Our only requirement is to abide by the club conduct found in our Discord(s)!
Summary: Gender-Inclusive Gaming is a social safe space that supports minorities who are interested in gaming of any variation as a leisure activity!

Name: GenKEY Sound Collective
Description: The GenKEY Sound Collective (GenKEY) is made up of Hanami GenKEY and Tsukimi GenKEY, the only Japanese Rock/Pop and R&B/Funk/Jazz bands on campus. Anyone is welcome to join regardless of background or experience! Contact us through our instagrams or emails.
Summary: GenKEY is a collective of non-audition bands that focus on Japanese Rock, Pop, R&B, Funk, and Jazz. Each band aims to amplify Japanese culture through music both on-campus and off!

Name: Global Medical Missions Alliance at Cal Poly
Description: GMMA at Cal Poly exists to spread God’s love by providing students a safe space and opportunity to further their faith through local community outreach, biweekly meetings, and participating in missions put on by the broader GMMA organization, so we can glorify him through our service. This ministry equips pre-health students in their careers and their faith if they are Christian or interested in learning more. Our 4 core values are of the following: Scripture, Prayer, Evangelism, and Missions.
Summary: Our chapter spreads God’s love by equipping pre-health students in both their careers and their faith (whether they are Christian or interested in exploring what it means to be a follower of Christ).

Name: Google Developer Student Clubs
Description: The Google Developer Student Club (GDSC) is a community group for students from any academic background in undergraduate or graduate programs. By joining GDSC, students build their professional network, get access to Google developer resources, and work together to build solutions for local problems in a peer-to-peer learning environment.
Summary: Google Developer Student Clubs (GDSC) are university-based community groups for students interested in Google technologies and programming. There are GDSCs in over 110 countries around the world that include undergraduate and graduate students.

Name: Graduate Planning Students Association
Description: The Purpose of the Graduate Planning Students Association is to explore, promote, and support academic understanding, professional development, and the overall advancement of the field of city and regional planning.
Summary: The Purpose of the Graduate Planning Students Association is to explore, promote, and support academic understanding, professional development, and the overall advancement of the field of city and regional planning.

Name: Graduate Student Association
Description:
-The official representative body of graduate students at Cal Poly-

The graduate student association focuses on creating a sense of community and belonging for graduate students, as well as advocating for graduate students across campus. We will be meeting on a monthly/bi-monthly basis, and hope to see you all there!
Summary: The official representative body of graduate students at Cal Poly
CategoryNames: College of Agriculture, Food & Environmental Science

Name: GrowCrew
Description: GrowCrew focuses on the designing, building, and maintenance of modern growing systems such as hydroponics. We operate a climate control room that houses our hydroponic units. The crops we grow range from leafy greens such as lettuce, cabbage, and bok choy. This club also has relationships with several partners in the modern growing industry. No previous agriculture experience required.
Summary: To promote the practice, awareness, and access to sustainable and innovative ideas for controlled environment agriculture.
CategoryNames: College of Agriculture, Food & Environmental Science

Name: Guardian Scholars
Description: The Guardian Scholars Program serves incoming first-year, transfer, and continuing undergraduate and graduate students who have experienced foster care or similar circumstances. We are committed to helping students earn a degree by providing a community of support where students can succeed and thrive.
Summary: Guardian Scholars, Office of Dean of Students

Name: Hack4Impact
Description:
We are a student-run 501(c)(3) organization that empowers engineers, designers, activists, and humanitarians to create lasting social change by developing projects for local nonprofits. We foster the wider adoption of software as a tool for social good.

 

https://youtu.be/yPG4dnN7uMY
Summary: We are a student-run 501(c)(3) organization that empowers engineers, designers, activists, and humanitarians to create lasting social change by developing projects for local nonprofits. We foster the wider adoption of software as a tool for social good.

Name: Her Campus at Cal Poly
Description:
Her Campus is a global online magazine targeted at the female college student demographic. Content in the magazine is written by more than 7,000 contributors from more than 400 campus chapters located in nine countries.

We are an online magazine catered to collegiate women but open to all. Joining our magazine is a great way to get real experience in the editorial, media, journalism, marketing, and event planning industry.
Summary: We are an online magazine catered to collegiate women but open to all. Joining our magazine is a great way to get real experience in the editorial, media, journalism, marketing, and event planning industry.

Name: Hillel of San Luis Obispo
Summary: San Luis Obispo Hillel is the center-point of Jewish life at Cal Poly and San Luis Obispo Community.  We provide a welcoming and supportive environment, so our students can be proud of and engaged with their Judaism.

Name: Hindu YUVA
Description: Hindu YUVA at Cal Poly aims to foster a supportive and inclusive community for Hindu students by organizing religious, cultural, and social events that celebrate and share the richness of Hindu heritage. Our mission is to promote awareness and understanding of Hindu values and traditions and give back to the broader San Luis Obispo community through activities like yoga workshops and community service. Stay connected and learn more about our upcoming events by visiting our Instagram page and Cal Poly Now!
Summary: Hindu YUVA is an event-oriented club and hosts quarterly social, cultural, and religious events. We aim to foster a supportive and inclusive community for Hindu and non-Hindu students through social and cultural events

Name: Hmong Student Association
Summary: The Hmong Student Association is a socio-cultural club whose aim is to foster a community with students who are Hmong or are interested in Hmong culture. This club emphasizes growth, inclusivity, and fun events!

Name: Horticulture Club
Summary: The purpose of this organization is to allow students interested in horticulture to socialize, learn about plants, grow plants in hands-on settings, and network with industry.
CategoryNames: College of Agriculture, Food & Environmental Science

Name: Huerta & Lewis Social Justice Residential Learning Community
Summary: Huerta & Lewis Social Justice Residential Learning Community

Name: Hui O Hawai'i
Description: Cal Poly Hui ‘O Hawai'i provides a home away from home for students from Hawai'i and a community for all those who are interested in the culture of Hawai'i. We seek to spread aloha through cultural and social events.
Summary: Cal Poly Hui ‘O Hawai'i provides a home away from home for students from Hawai'i and a community for all those who are interested in the culture of Hawai'i. We seek to spread aloha through cultural and social events.

Name: Human Resource Management Club
Description: The Human Resources & Management Association is open to all majors with a focus on professional development. We want to offer the students at Cal Poly a place to grow and learn about business, Human Resources, and management.
Summary: The Human Resources & Management Association is open to all majors with a focus on professional development. We want to offer the students at Cal Poly a place to grow and learn about business, Human Resources, and management.

Name: Hummus Club
Description: It is not HummYOU. It is HummUS!
Summary: A club for anyone who loves hummus and wants to see if they can enjoy it even more with fellow hummus friends on campus. Kick back, dip a chip, and have a good time. We hummus now.

Name: Ignite Consulting Junior Enterprise
Description:
We offer consulting services to the market, in relation to their fields of study (business). We each manage and execute these services. This gives us hands-on entrepreneurial & professional experience and the opportunity to impact our clients’ businesses.

Ignite Consulting is a non-profit organization dedicated to delivering tailored business solutions to companies in San Luis Obispo and the broader state of California. We embrace Cal Poly’s “Learn By Doing” approach, offering students hands-on experience to tackle real-world challenges. We prioritize teamwork, leadership, and academic excellence. Further, we leverage our extensive personal networks to access expert mentorship and valuable resources. By promoting professional and personal growth, we aim to create a community driven by collaboration, innovation, and shared success.

Key activities include:

  • Business: Market research & strategy, marketing & social media presence, website configuration, financial advising, etc.
  • Data Analysis: Business intelligence, consumer relationship management (CRM), enterprise data management (EDM), supply chain & operations, etc.
  • Product: Product placement, packaging, repositioning, etc.
Summary: Junior Enterprises aims to provide students of higher education with a unique learn by doing experience through managing and working with consulting firms/businesses.

Name: Imagen y Espiritu Ballet Folklorico de Cal Poly
Description: Imagen y Espíritu Ballet Folklórico de Cal Poly is a student-led dance club that performs traditional Mexican folk dance at various Cal Poly events and local community events. Students are encouraged to join in and learn about Mexican culture through dance while enhancing the participant's dancing abilities. No dance experience is needed to join!
Summary: Imagen y Espiritu Ballet Folklorico de Cal Poly is a student-led dance club participating in showcasing Mexican regional dances at various Cal Poly and local community events.

Name: Indian Students Association
Description: ISA is a cultural and social club open to all South Asian students. We aim to provide a diverse and inclusive environment for all of our members while utilizing our platform to highlight integral issues occurring in our community and world. Join us to celebrate all aspects of South Asian culture!
Summary: ISA is a cultural club open to all South Asian students. We aim to provide a diverse and inclusive environment for all of our members.

Name: Industrial Designers Society of America at Cal Poly
Description: IDSA is a professional club that welcomes students of all majors. We hold workshops that build product development and prototyping skills like sketching, rendering, 3D printing, and 3D modeling. We have professional skill building workshops where our club works on resumes, project portfolios and their LinkedIn presence. Our chapter works with the national IDSA organization to connect with guest speakers and provide networking opportunities like attending the annual International Design Conference, and Design Education Symposium.
Summary: Student Chapter of the Industrial Designers Society of America. Our mission is to create a space where students can gain design experience, build professional networks, and build technical skills.

Name: Information Systems Association
Description: Information Systems Association (ISA) is a professional networking club under OCOB that helps connect students with other IS students and companies for jobs and internship opportunities.
Summary: Information Systems Association(ISA) is a professional networking club under OCOB that helps connect companies and students for jobs and internship opportunities.

Name: Institute of Industrial and Systems Engineers
Summary: IISE is dedicated to the professional development, education, and involvement of all our members. Some of our events include info sessions with top industry representatives, socials, career fairs, and workshops. We welcome everyone whos interested!

Name: Institute of Transportation Engineers (ITE)
Description: https://youtu.be/-5o0CqpA0XI
Summary: ITE is an organization dedicated to connecting and educating transportation professionals.

Name: Inter Housing Council
Summary: Inter Housing Council is Cal Poly's residential student government comprised of three groups that enhance the resident experience.

Name: InterFraternity Council
Description: Governing body of Cal Poly social fraternity chapters.  Intermediary between chapters and the Cal Poly community/NIC
Summary: The governing body of Cal Poly Social Fraternities.

Name: International Student Friendship
Description:
Welcome!

ISF students come from all over the world and have different cultural, religious, and political backgrounds.  Yet we can all relate to relocating to a new country and are glad to have cross-cultural friendships.  We enrich our lives by learning from our friends firsthand about their parts of the world. 

 

Others too

Additionally, this club may be a great fit for some students who have been in the US for a while but have a strong attachment to their culture of origin.  For example, if your parents were immigrants who kept up their cultural practices and community here in the US, or students who came to the US for high school.  Anyone who appreciates what it takes to cross cultures.

 

The SLO Community Connection

A unique aspect of this club is our partnership with a group of SLO residents from local Christian churches. They volunteer their homes for amazing home-cooked dinners, good conversation, and fun activities.  It’s a home away from home.  Also, if students just ask, they are happy to help in many ways.
Summary: The ISF club's goal is to build lasting friendships among international students, scholars and American friends by caring for and fostering their unique interests: physical, social, emotional, and spiritual.

Name: InterVarsity Christian Fellowship San Luis Obispo
Description:
We believe that God is at work on college campuses and we want to be a part of what He is doing at Cal Poly. Together we learn what this means by studying God's word together and serving each other and the community. There are opportunities to build community through weekly small groups and large groups. We strive to be a community where all are welcome to do life with us and to be curious about who Jesus, whether you have been following Him your whole life or have very little idea of who Jesus is. 

Cal Poly video: https://youtu.be/XqOFB0xBdXo

IV USA Promo video: https://youtu.be/BzVE4Gz4uv4
Summary: InterVarsity SLO is a home for the spiritually curious that invites students and faculty from every cultural, spiritual, and ethnic background to be curious about who Jesus is and to experience God’s love as a family.

Name: Iranian Student Cultural Organization
Description:
ISCO is a non-political, non-religious student organization whose main objective is to host social activities & events to promote an understanding of our Persian culture while providing a safe environment to create friendships and a sense of community.

We work to uplift the voices of minorities, and promote an inclusive environment where everyone is respected and considered equal, regardless of race/ethnicity, gender, sexuality, religion, etc.

Despite what could be happening politically, our job as this campus' Persian club is to make sure that we are celebrating the best parts of our culture. This means we don't involve ourselves in any form of politics or religion whatsoever.

With around 10 current non-Persian ISCO members, we emphasize the fact that ISCO isn't a club that opens its arms to just Iranian students. It's a club that embraces and welcomes students of all kinds of backgrounds.
