Summary: ISCO is a non-political, non-religious student organization whose main objective is to host social activities & events to promote an understanding of our Persian culture while providing a safe environment to create friendships and a sense of community.

Name: Italian Cultural Association
Description: The Italian Cultural Association provides a space for students with Italian heritage, or those simply interested in Italian culture, to come together and build community. The ICA hosts regular meetings as well as events throughout the year!
Summary: The Italian Cultural Association provides a space for students with Italian heritage, or those simply interested in Italian culture, to come together and build community. The ICA hosts regular meetings as well as events throughout the year!

Name: iter8 at Cal Poly
Description: We are Cal Poly's first product design agency for students to gain hands-on product design experience. We create a positive space for students to collaborate in teams, design user experience solutions for startups, and develop their portfolios.
Summary: We are Cal Poly's first product design agency for students to gain hands-on Product Design experience. We create a positive space for students to collaborate in teams, design user experience solutions for startups, and develop their portfolios.

Name: Japanese Student Association
Description:
JSA is Cal Poly SLO's Japanese Student Association student club on campus. It operates as a non-profit social and cultural club, dedicated to sharing and celebrating Japanese culture in addition to fostering a JSA "family" community on campus. It's culture, community, & chaos - what more could you want?

JSA hosts weekly general meetings and weekend events, as well as project teams and SPORTS to keep your social calendar packed.  Like most culture clubs on campus, JSA also employs a “big-little” mentoring program that pairs older, experienced members with new members, a winter formal, and soubetsukai (our senior banquet) in the spring. We also are affiliated with the Japanese rock/pop band club called GenKEY, as well as a taiko group formed in collaboration with NSU!

JSA is open to all members of the Cal Poly SLO student body. Come be our friend!
Summary: Japanese Student Association (JSA) is a social and cultural club dedicated to sharing and celebrating Japanese culture.

Name: Kappa Alpha Theta, Zeta Theta
Description:
Welcome! We are the Zeta Theta chapter of Kappa Alpha Theta. Our organization was founded in Indiana in 1870, and our chapter was established at Cal Poly in 1989. We feel so lucky to share a little bit about our sisterhood and what our organization is all about!

Check out a little glimpse of our sisterhood!

Theta teaches us the importance of aspiring to something higher and envelops us in a sisterhood that is loyal and loving. Theta gives us challenges, opportunities, and dear friends. It supports learning and service and encourages philanthropy. Kappa Alpha Theta greatly broadens our world.
Summary: Theta teaches us the importance of aspiring to something higher and envelops us in a sisterhood that is loyal and loving.

Name: Kappa Kappa Gamma
Description:
Kappa Kappa Gamma is an organization of women which seeks for every member throughout her life to create bonds of friendship, mutual support, opportunities for self-growth, respect for intellectual development, and an understanding of an allegiance to positive ethical principles. The Eta Rho Chapter at Cal Poly San Luis Obispo supports several philanthropies including national and local organizations. Our national philanthropies include Active Minds and the Kappa Kappa Gamma Foundation. Our local philanthropy is the Central Coast Autism Spectrum Center. Our sisterhood is something that we hold near and dear to our hearts- to see a sneak peek of what our sisterhood looks like, check out this short video! 

https://youtu.be/kVbwJyqU_sU
Summary: Panhellenic chapter at Cal Poly that falls under Fraternity & Sorority Life. Kappa Kappa Gamma offers a member experience ranging from friendship to mentoring, from leadership to service, and from campus activities to a lifetime of community involvement.

Name: Kappa Kappa Psi - Iota Pi
Description:
Kappa Kappa Psi operates primarily as a student service and leadership recognition society whose chief aim is to assist the Director of Bands in developing the leadership and enthusiasm that is required of their band.

Iota Pi is the Cal Poly, San Luis Obispo chapter of Kappa Kappa Psi, a co-ed national honorary fraternity for college bandmembers.
Summary: Kappa Kappa Psi operates primarily as a student service and leadership recognition society whose chief aim is to assist the Director of Bands in developing the leadership and enthusiasm that is required of their band.

Name: Kappa Pi Chapter of Pi Kappa Phi Fraternity
Summary: Pi Kappa Phi is a national men's fraternity founded on leadership in 1904 at the College of Charleston. We are now 120,000 strong, & on more than 180 campuses.

Name: Kesem at Cal Poly
Description:
At Camp Kesem Cal Poly SLO we strive to create and maintain a community of support for families through and beyond the cancer of a parent. We do this through year-round support services, community events, and our week-long sleep away summer camp (all at no cost to our families)! Our chapter fundraises and raises awareness throughout the year so that we can bring Kesem magic to the San Luis Obispo County and beyond! Check out our Camp 2023 video for a glimpse into what we do!

As a college student, you can get involved in our chapter by attending our monthly meetings, fundraising, joining a committee, or applying to be a summer camp counselor. Click here to join our mailing list for more info!
Summary: Kesem is a national nonprofit organization dedicated to supporting children through and beyond a parent's cancer, by hosting a week-long summer camp and fostering a year-round community.

Name: Kinesiology and Public Health Student Government
Summary: The Kinesiology Club is run by the Kinesiology and Public Health Student Council. We hope to connect all KPH students and faculty and we strive to provide students and faculty with both fun & informational events that will enrich their time at Cal Poly.

Name: Korean American Student Association
Description:
Take a look at what some of our members think!

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sAo7jJzBZ48
Summary: KASA (Korean American Student Association) is a Korean cultural and social club that offers a welcoming environment for anyone and everyone!

Name: KPOP Dance Crew
Description: Kaja Krew (also known as K2) is a non-audition K-pop dance cover crew that is open to students from all levels of experience. "Kaja" (가자) is a Korean phrase translating to "let's go," and it is often used to motivate and encourage others. In essence, Kaja Krew invites people to dance, have fun, and be a part of an energetic and passionate community.
Summary: A dance club specializing in K-pop, we are an all levels and experience welcome, inclusive community that consistently performs and records covers.

Name: Lambda Chi Alpha - Phi Sigma Zeta
Description: Lambda Chi Alpha is a philanthropic organization with an emphasis on growing young men into leaders of tomorrow.
Summary: on-campus fraternity

Name: Lambda Pi Eta
Description:
Lambda Pi Eta is the Cal Poly branch of the National Communication Studies honor society. The organization recognizes the outstanding academic achievements of Communication Studies majors and admits members based on GPA and the number of COMS units taken.

LPH meets once per quarter and has one social, one academic/professional, and one volunteer event per year. The club also hosts other events, such as chats with our advisor. Additionally, the club hosts induction events for new members and an annual senior sendoff ceremony.
Summary: Lambda Pi Eta is a Communication Studies honor society.

Name: Lambda Sigma Gamma
Description:
Lambda Sigma Gamma Sorority, Incorporated was founded on October 24, 1986, by 27 women at California State University, Sacramento. Our founder, Linda V. Fuentes recruited 26 others in order to start an organization that would act as a family away from home. They built this organization on the basis of uniting women from different backgrounds and provide one another with educational support, encourage each other's self-improvement, and create leaders.

 

Today, thousands of diverse women have come together, devoted to self-improvement, scholastic excellence, and civic responsibility. Lambda Sigma Gamma Sorority, Inc. now has 27 chapters across California, Arizona, and Oregon  - each dedicated to empowering women.

 

Lambda Sigma Gamma Sorority, Inc. is continuously growing, uniting women, and building everlasting friendships.

 

Cal Poly LSG would love to get to know you! If you have any questions about Lambda Sigma Gamma, please contact us!
Summary: Lambda Sigma Gamma is a multicultural sorority that strives on the diversity of its members. We are an organization that focuses of on our five pillars: Professionalism, Academics,Philanthropy, Sisterhood, & Multiculturalism.

Name: Lambda Theta Phi Latin Fraternity, Inc.
Description: Lambda Theta Phi Latin Fraternity, Inc. was founded at Kean College in Union, New Jersey on December 1, 1975. The ideals of our brotherhood are the following: Academic Excellence; Brotherhood; Leadership; Latino Unity; Service. On a daily basis, our brothers live up to these ideals, as set forth by fourteen young Latino men decades ago.
Summary: Lambda Theta Phi Latin Fraternity, Inc. was founded at Kean College in Union, New Jersey on December 1, 1975. We strive for academic success, and uphold our core values of Unity, Respect, Brotherhood, Culture, and Pride.

Name: Latine/x Center For Academic Success and Student Achievement (LaCASA)
Description:
The Latine/x Center for Academic Success and Achievement (LaCASA), rooted in community and joy, provides activities for all students. LaCASA hosts Heritage month programing, conduct field trips, support Latine/x cultural organization events, and create fun events rooted in the diverse needs and experiences of Latinx students. Look below for the full list of our quarterly events. 

 

Where is the center located: 

Building 15 room 135

 

When is the center open: 

The center is generally open Monday through Friday 9am – 5pm. 

 

Center Offerings: 

We provide an accessible computer lab which includes free printing (10 pages per day per student). LaCASA is a multipurpose space used for studying, resting, social gatherings and hosting programs/events while also serving students’ basic needs via food cabinet, snacks, and more. 

Past Event Highlights: 

Throughout the year we host many events, check the feed below to register for our upcoming events. Below are the descriptions of past events: 

Dia De Los Muertos: 
An annual event that is tradition for many within Latin America, such as Mexico, to celebrate and honor deceased relatives and welcome their souls through ornate ofrendas (altars), décor, sweets such as pan de muerto and other cultural artifacts. All are invited to create their own ofrendas on campus at the UU Plaza! 

Latine/x Heritage Month: 
Typically occurring early in the fall quarter, LaCASA will host special events and programs highlighting critical issues that impact the Latine/x diaspora and honor the cultural significance of this comunidad.  

Cafecito con Pan Dulce: 
A proud partnership with the Native American and Indigenous Cultural Center, we host quarterly sessions for our student communities to come together and enjoy coffee with pan dulce.  

Self-Care Events:  
Quarterly programs hosted by LaCASA student staff that offer opportunities to center self and community care. Examples include Karaoke fun, paint or arts activities, workshops, game nights and more! 

Mental Health Check-Ins : 

Monthly drop-ins with a BIPOC-focused mental health counselor of Cal Poly’s health and wellbeing service. This can serve as a processing and dialogue space centering issues and topics brought up by our LaCASA student community. 

IG: @calpoly_lacasa
Summary: Nurturing the Latine/x community and their intersectional experiences through transformational programming such as cultural celebrations, educational opportunities, and events centering comunidad. Register for this quarter’s events in our profile.

Name: Latinos in Agriculture
Description:
Latinos in Agriculture aims to promote diversity and higher education for all students in CAFES. We foster students' success by bringing professional and academic opportunities to our members during our general meetings and by participating in campus activities like Week of Welcome, PolyCultural Weekend, & Culturefest. LIA members have the opportunity to plan and host our annual events 26 Hours of Science and Technology in Agriculture, DATE: Discovering Agriculture the Transfer Experience, and Empoderando Mujeres in Agriculture where they have the opportunity to grow as leaders, work in teams, and connect with campus resources.

Latinos in Agriculture is the local chapter of MANRRS, a national society promoting academic and professional advancement by empowering minorities in agriculture, natural resources, and related sciences. Latinos in Agriculture offers opportunities for competition, networking, and travel through regional and national MANRRS conferences.
Summary: Latinos in Agriculture (LIA) is a professional and cultural organization dedicated to providing a home away from home for underrepresented students in the College of Agriculture, Food, and Environmental Sciences (CAFES).
CategoryNames: College of Agriculture, Food & Environmental Science

Name: Latinos in Veterinary Medicine
Description: Latinos in Veterinary Medicine (LVM) is a student-led organization dedicated to supporting Latinx students pursuing careers in veterinary medicine. We aim to create a culturally affirming space that offers mentorship, professional development, and community-building opportunities. Through guest speakers, skill-building workshops, and social events, LVM empowers members to navigate the veterinary field with confidence and pride in their identity.
Summary: LVM strives to create a supportive and empowering space for Latino students in veterinary medicine, fostering mentorship, professional development, and a sense of community.
CategoryNames: College of Agriculture, Food & Environmental Science

Name: Latinx Business Student Association
Description: LBSA hopes to encourage and promote the development of tomorrow's future leaders from all backgrounds and career fields. We strive to equip every member with the fundamental skills, relationships, and expertise necessary to successfully launch their professional careers. As the only cultural club in the Orfalea College of Business, LBSA is geared towards fortifying the academic and professional goals of underrepresented students by unifying and empowering our growing community. LBSA welcomes students from any of the six academic colleges. Our pillars are family, professionalism, academics, and community service. Find your home away from home here at LBSA
Summary: Latinx Business Student Association

Name: Latinx Cultura Creativa
Description: Our mission is to empower, uplift, and support Latinx students within the College of Liberal Arts by fostering a strong community, celebrating our diverse cultural identities, and promoting academic and personal growth. We are committed to creating a safe and inclusive space where Latinx voices are heard, valued, and encouraged. Through mentorship, advocacy, and cultural events, we aim to inspire leadership, build connections, and enhance representation in the college and beyond, while raising awareness of the unique experiences and contributions of Latinx students at our institution.
Summary: Our mission is to empower, uplift, and support Latinx students within the College of Liberal Arts by fostering a strong community, celebrating our diverse cultural identities, and promoting academic and personal growth.

Name: Latinx Cultural Association
Description: Latinx Cultural Association (LCA) strives to create a community and safe place to learn, share, as well as experience Latinx culture and practices. We aspire to promote an environment in which everyone of the Cal Poly community feels welcome, all while having the opportunity to appreciate the diverse Latinx heritages. Our goal is to provide a space for members to express themselves and showcase their various abilities through participation in club activities. We hope to promote leadership through opportunities in which our members can create an impact in the community and promote the culture.
Summary: LCA strives to create a fun social environment to learn, share and experience Latinx culture and practices. We aspire to promote a welcoming community open to everyone and give the opportunity to appreciate the various heritages of the Latinx community.

Name: Leadership & Service
Description:
Leadership & Service consists of four units:

Center for Leadership

Center for Service in Action

Clubs & Organizations

Fraternity & Sorority Life
Summary: A Department of Cal Poly Student Affairs

Name: Learn by Doing Good Awards
ShortName: Leadership and Engagement Achievement of Distinction
Description:
Since 1986, Cal Poly's Community Service Awards were presented to students, faculty, staff, and community partner agencies for their contributions to the quality of life in San Luis Obispo and their spirit of civic engagement.  Awards were given to highlight specific achievements in service. Past recipients can be found HERE.

Since 2017, the LEAD Awards recognized students, student organizations, programs, and events in Student Affairs for on-campus achievements in Leadership, Engagement, Advocacy, and Distinction.  

2022 LEAD Awards

  • Collaboration // Arie To; Manuela Cruz (Educators of Color)
  • Leadership in Action // Anthony Choe, Rashmi Pradhan, & Ricardo Villanueva (Design Village); Cheryl Flores; Maddie Vallado; Oscar Velasco
  • Program or Event of Distinction // Camp PolyHacks Hackathon
  • Allyship // Yovani Alexander

In 2024, we are delighted to announce the combined and collaborative presentation of the inaugural Learn by Doing Good Awards for service, leadership, and engagement on and off campus.  The awards are selected on the basis of written nominations by a panel of faculty, staff and students. President Armstrong will bestow and personally recognize award recipients for their efforts.
Summary: The Learn by Doing Good Awards honor students, faculty, staff, and organizations who participate in service to the campus and community. It combines the Community Service Awards and LEAD Awards into a new event for 2024.

Name: Letters of Love
Description:
Letters of Love has had the honor of providing emotional support to over 300,000 patients in Children’s Hospitals around the world. It is a way for everyone to be able to make a difference without having to worry about their personal financial situation; a way for young people to help without having to worry about money. It is a club where students have the opportunity to emotionally support children battling cancer and other serious illnesses. Students can come and make cards for patients at Children’s Hospitals around the world. 

 

Join the GroupMe for meeting information! https://groupme.com/join_group/88101514/nZVyAhmn
Summary: A club where students can come together to have the opportunity to make letters of encouragement to children and families of those who are in hospitals around the world.

Name: Liberal Arts and Engineering Studies Club
Description: The LAES Club welcomes all Cal Poly students interested in creative technologies, providing them with opportunities to collaborate on interdisciplinary projects and learn about/network with industry members.  This is a great place to meet other students in the LAES program, learn more about the major, and get involved with unique and interdisciplinary LAES projects. Students from all disciplines are welcome!
Summary: Liberal Arts and Engineering Studies

Name: Life Skills Program
Description:
The Life Skills Program at Cal Poly empowers students to build essential life skills that enable them to thrive academically, personally, and professionally within a supportive and inclusive community. 

 

Located within the Office of the Dean of Students, the Life Skills Program offers engaging, interactive life skills workshops and personalized one-on-one sessions. We help students develop knowledge, skills and a support network necessary to navigate life confidently in the areas of:

  • Money management
  • Cyber literacy
  • Nutrition
  • Wellness and stress reduction
  • Living independently
  • Healthy communication
  • Healthy relationships
  • Conflict resolution
  • Career readiness

 

Sponsored by the Guardian Scholars Program
Summary: The Life Skills Program in the Office of the Dean of Students empowers students to build essential life skills to thrive academically, personally and professionally.

Name: Los Lecheros Dairy Club
Description:
A part of Cal Poly since 1932, the Los Lecheros Dairy Club is currently the longest consecutively chartered club in the College of Agriculture, Food and Environmental Sciences. We are a club passionate about getting involved in the dairy industry, making a friendly community on campus and having fun!

We have monthly meetings where we discuss industry topics, get competitively involved in intramural sports, participate in CAFES events, and leave a mark on the dairy industry. 

Instagram: @los.lecheros
Summary: Los Lecheros Dairy Club was formed for all those passionate about sharing a common interest in the field of dairy science.
CategoryNames: College of Agriculture, Food & Environmental Science

Name: Marine Sciences Club
Description: The Marine Sciences Club works to unite everyone with a passion for marine science. Our goals are to build community, offer members connections to opportunities, foster learning, and have fun! We have biweekly meetings, with a mix of workshops, guest speakers, games, and other events. All ocean lovers are welcome, regardless of major, discipline, or year!
Summary: The Marine Sciences Club works to unite students across all disciplines who have a passion for marine sciences. We aim to build community, offer members connections to opportunities, and have fun!

Name: Mat Pica Pi
Summary: Mat Pica Pi is Graphic Communication's social and professional development club. We aim to connect all generations of GrC, as well as connect our students with professional career opportunities.

Name: Math Club
Description: While Math Club does serve as a place of community for Math Majors specifically, we are proud to invite people throughout the Cal Poly community to come by and mingle. This is a social club first and foremost, and serving as a place where students feel welcomed and appreciated, regardless of their level of involvement in the Math Department or the University in general, is one of Math Club's primary purposes.
Summary: Math Club serves as an organized and scheduled social hour where all math-associated students of Cal Poly meet to fraternize and make connections.

Name: MBA Student Association
Description:
The purpose of this organization is to create opportunities for Cal Poly MBA students to further their educational and professional development and be a resource for students to connect to professionals within the business world.

  • Feedback is direct and kind 
  • Value honest communication  
  • Respect time: stay on task (not lost in detail) and be on time 
  • In events, we value quality, honor deadlines, and inform all relevant parties
Summary: The purpose of this organization is to create opportunities for Cal Poly MBA students to further their educational and professional development and be a resource for students to connect to professionals within the business world.

Name: Mechanical Contractors Association of America
Description: MCAA focuses on mechanical systems and plumbing contracting and interacts with industry partners to provide a deeper understanding. We host a golf tournament fundraiser in Napa Valley California, travel to MCAA conferences, and have in depth trainings with general and specialty contractors. Mechanical systems and plumbing are not taught heavily at Cal Poly and participating in this team is a unique way to learn about those systems, and become an integral member of any construction company.
Summary: MCAA competes in several mechanical competitions, fundraises with industry, and travels to conferences. Our Team simulates proposals of a mechanical and plumbing contractor and provides a unique and informative understanding of specialty contracting.

Name: Men and Masculinities Program (MnM)
Description:
The Men and Masculinites Program engages the Cal Poly community with the purpose of creating spaces to critically evaluate ideas and expressions of masculinities and their intersections with men’s health and wellbeing. Through educational and community building programming such as dialogue and affinity groups, MnM seeks to facilitate the growth and support of male-identifying students, men of color, trans men, and masculine-adjacent student populations. The program was originally designed to engage men and the culture of masculinity on campus toward the goal of ending sexual assault through efforts focused on gender-based violence prevention. Over the years the program has evolved to increase its support of marginalized masculine identities and has expanded opportunities for all students to engage in conversations about masculinity, the socialization of gender norms, and gender identity development.  

Where it is located: UU 209 (new location as of Winter 2023)  

When is the center open: 9-5pm  

What can I do in the center:  

computer, community space, dialogues, health resources, queer resources, education, basic needs  

 

Insert about center events  

Movember  

Movember is M&M’s annual men’s health awareness month, featuring a series of events, dialogues, workshops, etc. highlighting a specific theme related to men’s health. Past themes have included: Black Men’s Health; Masculinities & Mental Health; and Changing the Face of Men’s Health. 

The Shop 

The Shop is a community event for men of color to access local barber services that have the skillset to support them. Haircuts are pre-paid for students (who are encouraged to tip their barber); pizza dinner is provided as well. 

Manifest 

Manifest is an annual gender-based art exhibit dedicated to exploring how aspects of masculinity are portrayed in our culture through art. 

Pass the Mic 

PTM is an open mic event featuring student speakers, engaging media pieces, group discussion, and open mic segments. This event focuses on providing students with a platform to hear about, discuss, and share perspective on a variety of topics related to masculinities. 

Men of Color Success Initiative 

MOCSI is designed to support undergraduate and graduate men of color at Cal Poly with a dynamic community of peer and faculty/staff mentors who create a network of social, professional, and academic support. This network serves to further develop mentees’ self-identity, and to increase their sense of community, engagement, and persistence towards achieving their degree. MOCSI provides students with mentorship opportunities, affinity-based dialogue spaces, and with educational events geared towards promoting intersectionality. 

FSL Healthy Masculinities Week  

Fraternity & Sorority Life Healthy Masculinities Week (FSLHMW) is a week-long event series focusing on elevating the conversation about healthy masculinities within fraternity and sorority student communities. 

Educational Events  

MnM provides a variety of educational events throughout the year such as a Book Circle on the “Will to Change” by Bell Hooks, a Masculinity and Me Panel, Mansplaining Bingo, and Anatomy of a Nice Guy.
Summary: Collaborating to develop healthy masculinities we create educational events and spaces for men of color and marginalized masculine identities to discuss gender identity, expression, and intersectionality. Register for this quarter’s events in our profile

Name: Men's Health & Wellbeing Club
Description: The Men’s Health & Wellbeing Club aims to educate, support, and unite young college men who are seeking to improve their lives in a holistic way. This entails focusing on aspects of their physical, mental, and social/relational life, to collectively work toward becoming the men they aspire to be. Through a variety of education-based activities, open discussions, as well as social events, we hope to create a brotherhood that promotes a lifestyle contagious to others. Some of the qualities we aim to embody include integrity, accountability, respectfulness, and selflessness.
Summary: The Men’s Health & Wellbeing Club aims to educate, support, and unite young college men who are seeking to improve their lives in a holistic way. We provide resources, tools, and community to promote a healthy physical, mental, and social lifestyle.

Name: Men's Soccer Club
Description: All important updates and announcements regarding tryouts and other events for the upcoming season will be posted and found on the club's Instagram page: @calpolymenssoccerclub
Summary: The Cal Poly Men's Soccer Club has grown into one of the top college club soccer programs in the Nation. Fielding 2 full squads, we regularly compete with the best teams in the state as well as the country in league, regional, and national matches.

Name: Men's Volleyball
Description: https://youtu.be/wUfrvwTNUJQ
Summary: A competitive men's volleyball program that plays matches and tournaments in the Northern California Collegiate Volleyball League. We field 2 teams that both play in the National Championships put on by the National Collegiate Volleyball Federation.

Name: Men's Volleyball Club
Summary: Cal Poly Maritime Academy's Men's Club Volleyball exists to provide an organized opportunity for Cadets and Students to participate in a competitive environment to compete against other teams through the NCVF.

Name: Mercy College Movement
Description: MCM is a club through a nearby church called Local Church (previously Mercy Church) that provides services on campus on Sunday nights and organizes meetings to proclaim the name of Jesus on Cal Poly’s campus! We are also known as Local College Movement (LoCo).
Summary: MCM is a club through a local church called Mercy Church that provides services on campus on Sunday nights, and organizes meetings to proclaim the name of Jesus on Cal Poly's campus!

Name: MESS
Summary: The Materials Engineering Student Society hosts events for MATE students and offers opportunities to collaborate, study, socialize, and gain information about career options and research.

Name: Middle Eastern and North African
Summary: MENA is a non-religious cultural club which aims to celebrate and share the diverse cultures within the Middle East and North African diaspora, while also striving to foster a sense of community for MENA-identifying students at Cal Poly.

Name: Military Science Club (MSC)
Summary: MSC is a social group where CP students and ROTC cadets can come together for friendly gatherings, compete in entertaining games, participate in volunteer events, and have many opportunities to relax and have some fun!

Name: Minna No Anime
Summary: Minna no Anime is a group formed to promote, discuss, and appreciate Japanese animation.

Name: Minorities in Physics (MiP)
Summary: We provide a space for underrepresented identities in physics to connect with one another, talk about common issues/struggles, and ultimately create a supportive and positive community.

Name: MultiCultural Center (MCC)
Description:
The MultiCultural Center began its time fostering students’ growth and understanding of their own power through intersectionality and activism. This center has continued to evolve and has only elevated its programming, events and resources to ensure all students develop their sense of belonging. Some signature programs that the MCC is known for that have supported our students in their own identity development include; Culture Fest, PolyCultural Weekend, Student of Color Summit and more! The MCC is a space that serves all but will always aim to uplift the most marginalized at Cal Poly. These student communities may include folx from the Asian American, Pacific Islander, and Desi American (APIDA); Southwest Asian and North African (SWANA); and Multiracial/ethnic (mixed) communities.  

 
Location: 

Room 111F University Union (065-111F). It's located next to the craft center and across from the University Union Market on the lower level. 

 
Operating Hours: 

Staffed Hours: Monday – Friday 9:00am-5:00pm.  

 
Space open to students: 

The center is open to students during normal university union operating hours regardless of whether staff are present. 

 
Center Space Offerings: 

Identity exploration programing, student organization event space, printing, napping, a kitchenette, desktop computers, social events, blankets, squish mellows, study space, and snacks.  

 

Programing: 

The center staff focuses on creating programs that foster a sense of belonging among students: 

Culture Fest: 

Annual celebration where cultural student organizations showcase food, music, dance, and other elements. 
 

PolyCultural Weekend: 

PolyCultural Weekend aims to serve underrepresented minority groups by connecting prospective students with the cultural community on campus. Our goal is to create an inclusive and welcoming environment where students are able to find their home away from home. 

During the weekend, prospective students will explore academic, cultural, and social resources. The weekend experience will help students establish a sense of community, cultivate a feeling of belonging, and gain the confidence to succeed at Cal Poly. 

 

Mixed Mixers: 

Opportunities for multiracial, multiethnic, and mixed students to come together in community. 

 

Lunar New Year (Spring Festival): 

This holiday is celebrated across many APIDA communities. During this celebration, the MCC offers activities, crafts and food for all to take part in.  
 

Heritage Month Programming: 

The center hosts programming for a variety of different cultures during their cultural months (mainly APIDA and SWANA). These programs focus on being cross cultural and inclusive.  

IG: calpoly_mcc
Summary: The original cultural center at Cal Poly, the center continues to evolve as it serves all communities. We facilitate programs, events and resources to ensure all students develop their sense of belonging. Register for this quarter’s events in our profile

Name: Muslim Students Organization
Description: The Cal Poly San Luis Obispo Muslim Student Association (MSA) is a club and family of students on campus that strives to provide a safe and inclusive space for students to discover, practice, and express their faith. It aims to offer religious services, support Muslim students on campus, and provide resources. The goal is to better the community around us through volunteering, advocacy, and community projects. It hopes to expand awareness regarding Islam and to educate anyone wishing to join the club. All are welcome regardless of faith, and we look forward to meeting and getting to know you!
Summary: The MSA is a space for students to gather to learn and grow in the Muslim faith, and it provides resources and support for Muslim students on campus.

Name: Mustang Aviation Club
Description: Mustang Aviation Club provides students with an outlet to explore the world of aviation. We introduce and cultivate a passion for flying, airplanes, and immerse our club members in the local aviation community! This includes fun events at the airport, guest speakers from a wide range of flying careers, and even introductory flight lessons! Every year we teach an FAA private pilot ground school course during winter quarter and are able to endorse our students to take the written exam and begin their flight training. Students of any major and all experience levels are welcome!
Summary: The Mustang Aviation Club advances the science of aeronautics, to develop aviation and to educate pilots in every way towards safe operations.

Name: Mustang Band Club
Description:
Welcome to Mustang Band: The Pride of the Pacific and The Smartest Band on the West Coast!

 

https://youtu.be/GFLLza7_xSQ

 

We are a group of individuals comprised of varying majors and backgrounds that come together during the fall and winter to provide spirit and music for Cal Poly athletic, campus, and community events. Read below for more information about what we do and FAQs. 

 

FOOTBALL GAMES

During the Fall quarter, Mustang Band meets as a class to prepare for football games, where we play pregame, halftime, and postgame routines in addition to other performances on campus throughout the day. Check out this playlist for some past halftime shows! Mustang Band Field Shows

 

PEP GAMES

In addition to football games, we also support other teams: volleyball, basketball, wrestling, and sometimes baseball throughout their seasons and continuing on with championship tournaments. The band is usually split into three different groups that play throughout the Fall and Winter quarters.


OTHER CAMPUS EVENTS

We also play for various events throughout the year, including Big Fall Welcome during WoW, Poly Royal Parade during Open House, the SLO Holiday Parade, and more!

 

CHINESE NEW YEAR PARADE

The Chinese New Year Parade in San Francisco is a travel opportunity that we always enjoy participating in. We prepare during the Winter quarter and spend the weekend in San Francisco. There, we participate in a Battle of the Bands with another band (usually UC Davis) before playing in the parade itself. 

 

 

FAQ

How do I join?

Please fill out this Interest Form and follow these instructions to audition. You can also reach out to either the directors or current officers in the band if you'd like to receive more information. 

 

How much experience do I need to join?

Although we expect everyone to know how to play their instruments, we take people of all marching experience levels (those who have never marched to those that have participated in drum corps) and teach them our marching style and basics during band camp right before school starts. 

 

How much time commitment is there?

Band camp occurs during WoW before school starts and the fall time commitment includes practices twice a week in addition to 3 pep games and a total of about 5 Saturday football games throughout Fall quarter. During Winter quarter, the time commitment includes one practice a week with a total of 5 pep games and optional participation to practice and perform in the Chinese New Year Parade.

 

What is the community like?

Mustang Band is a family that loves spending time together and supporting each other, whether it be in our music endeavors, personal lives, or through our academic interests. Throughout your years at Cal Poly, you can trust that Mustang Band members will be there to make new friendships, take classes together, and enjoy playing music together. 

 

How do current members balance school and band?

Most of our current members balance a full course load in addition to Mustang Band. With the minimal time commitment throughout each quarter, it is often thought of as a break from academically rigorous classes and an opportunity to unwind.
Summary: The Mustang Band is a large group of brass, woodwind, percussion, and color guard performers that provide entertainment at Cal Poly athletic events.

Name: Mustang Consulting at Cal Poly
Description: cpmustangconsulting.com
Summary: The purpose of Mustang Consulting is to provide pro bono consulting services to various organizations, community groups, and other entities in need, while providing professional development opportunities for its members.

Name: Mustang Surf Club
Description:
Hi Cal Poly Mustangs! 

We are a new club on campus looking to bring the Cal Poly surfing community closer together through hosting social functions and surf-related activities. We offer surf lessons!

If you're interested, check us out on instagram and we'll add you to our Slack messaging group. We would love to support you along your surfing journey and connect you with other surfers in our community! (Accepting students at any skill level)

Send inquiries via Instagram @mustangsurfclub or mustangsurfclub@gmail.com

Our linktree has a link to our slack page to stay in the loop.
Summary:
Mustang Surf Club is an interest-based social group looking to foster a community of surfers at Cal Poly through social events. 
We are open to all surfing skill levels and to those who wish to cultivate a surfing lifestyle with their fellow Mustangs.

Name: Mustangs for Recovery
Description: At Mustangs for Recovery, we honor recovery from substance and behavioral addictions as both a return to wellness and a process of healing. As a program of Campus Health & Wellbeing, we exist to offer a safe and sober-friendly environment for students in recovery, seeking recovery, or those affected by the addiction of a friend or family member. Our purpose is to offer alternatives, support, community, and events geared toward students in recovery. We offer meetings based in both abstinence-only and harm-reduction models.
Summary: Mustangs for Recovery exists to offer a safe and sober-friendly environment for students in recovery, seeking recovery, or those affected by the addiction of a friend or family member.

Name: Mustangs United for Israel
Description: Mustangs United For Israel (MUFI) is the pro-Israel, pro-peace coalition with the mission of promoting open bipartisan dialogue, advocating for the Jewish Democratic State of Israel. MUFI fosters a respectful and inclusive environment where diverse perspectives on Israel can be shared and explored. Through educational events, cultural programming, and campus engagement, we aim to strengthen understanding, combat misinformation, and build bridges at Cal Poly SLO.
Summary: Mustangs United For Israel (MUFI) is the pro-Israel, pro-peace coalition with the mission of promoting open bipartisan dialogue, advocating for the Jewish Democratic State of Israel.

Name: National Association of Minority Landscape Architects
Description: NAMLA’s purpose is to increase minority representation and create a safe space for minorities and allies to have open conversations about diversity at all levels of Landscape Architecture.
Summary: NAMLA’s purpose is to increase minority representation at all levels of Landscape Architecture practice and academia.

Name: National Electrical Contractors Association
Description: A club designed to work together to solve a problem and create a proposal for sustainable electrical designs within construction.
Summary: Cal Poly National Electrical Contractors Association, student chapter.

Name: National Marrow Donor Program
Description:
At NMDP℠, we believe each of us holds the key to curing blood cancers and disorders. As a global nonprofit leader in cell therapy, NMDP creates essential connections between researchers and supporters to inspire action and accelerate innovation to find life-saving cures.

Our Mission

We save lives through cell therapy.

Our Vision

Create a world where every patient can receive their life-saving cell therapy.
Summary: At NMDP℠, we believe each of us holds the key to curing blood cancers and disorders. As a global nonprofit leader in cell therapy, NMDP creates essential connections between researchers and supporters to inspire action.

Name: National Organization of Minority Architect Students
Description: NOMAS is the student branch of the National Organization of Minority Architects (NOMA). NOMA’s purpose is to champion diversity within the design profession by promoting the excellence, community engagement, and professional development of its professional and student members. NOMA is all about opportunity – members become part of a network of over 500+ professionals and over 50 student chapters nationwide. This extensive network provides members with opportunities to network and develop crucial professional relationships. The mentorship and support openly shared between the professional members and students is truly unique and often leads to internships and full time employment opportunities upon graduation.
Summary: NOMAS is the student branch of the National Organization of Minority Architects (NOMA). NOMA’s purpose is to champion diversity within the design profession by promoting the excellence, community engagement, and professional development of its members.

Name: National Society of Black Engineers
Description:
Cal Poly SLO NSBE Promo Video

Welcome the best collegiate NSBE Chapter on the entire West Coast!!! Winners of back-to-back-to-back Regional Chapter of the Year Awards (2021, 2020, 2019), our NSBE Chapter strives to support present-day Cal Poly STEM students academically and professionally by leveraging our Black alumni of the past, all while cultivating culturally responsible engineers and scientists for the future. Check out our website calpolyslonsbe.com to learn more
Summary: NSBE's mission is to increase the number of culturally responsible Black engineers who excel academically, succeed professionally, and positively impact the community.
CategoryNames: College of Agriculture, Food & Environmental Science

Name: Native American and Indigenous Cultural Center (NAICC)
Description:
The Native American and Indigenous Cultural Center acknowledges that the Cal Poly campus is situated on unceded land, included in the unratified Treaty “C” region, signed at Camp Burton on June 3, 1851. We recognize yak titʸu titʸu yak tiłhini [Northern Chumash Tribe of San Luis Obispo County and Region], their continuing connection to land, water, and community, and yak titʸu titʸu yak tiłhini elder's past, present, and emerging.  

   

The Native American and Indigenous Cultural Center is an intertribal space that seeks to embrace and encourage students to (re)connect to the traditions and cultures of Native American and Indigenous peoples. The center aims to ensure student success by holistically supporting them and providing services rooted in de-colonial practices, community engagement, restorative healing, and native knowledge. Our vision is to create and sustain an environment where Native and Indigenous students thrive and contribute to the university's efforts to recruit, retain, and graduate Native and Indigenous students.   

 

Location: 

Located in the administration building of the yak titʸu titʸu housing complex (Building 172H). It's located after the community room before the mail center in room 172H1-46.  

 
Operating Hours: 

When staff are available its open Monday – Friday 9:00am - 5:00pm, the center does not remain open without staff present. 

 
Center Space Offerings: Is everything here? 

Academic support, basic needs food cabinet, student clothing, community space, microwave 

Signature events:  

Indigenous Peoples’ Day: 

Join us in October, as we celebrate and honor indigenous peoples and commemorate their story and culture. 

Native American Heritage Month: 
Occurring the month of November, NAICC will host special events and programs highlighting the Native American community to honor native culture.
Summary: Aiming to create a pan-indigenous space, we recognize the vast diversity within the Indigenous community by providing a nurturing environment, educational programming, and a place to empower growth. Register for this quarter’s events in our profile.

Name: NerdFlare
Description:
https://youtu.be/NALADKYsrc0


    NerdFlare is an interdisciplinary student group that teaches students how to design and create printed circuit board (PCB) artwork, known as badges and add-ons called SAOs. We hold various beginner-friendly workshops covering embedded programming, circuit design, and art with the end goal of creating your own badge. We also work on projects for on and off-campus organizations. No experience is needed, just curiosity and a willingness to learn!

 

More Information:

 https://discord.com/invite/X8QYvA5CRN
Summary: NerdFlare is an interdisciplinary student group that teaches students how to design and create printed circuit board (PCB) artwork. We hold various beginner-friendly workshops covering programming, circuit design, and art.

Name: Net Impact
Description:
Here at Net Impact SLO we believe in the power of business to bring positive change to the world’s most pressing social and environmental challenges.

By providing opportunities to make an impact firsthand and interact with industry leaders, Net Impact helps members develop a broader perspective, grow an extensive network, and gain experience in scaling their impact beyond individual actions.

Through a global community of more than 100,000 students, Net Impact has helped thousands of emerging leaders build successful “impact careers” — either by working in jobs dedicated to change or by bringing a social and environmental lens to traditional business roles.

Get involved today to help turn ideas into powerful initiatives on campus and in the San Luis Obispo community. We meet on Thursdays from 11:10am-12pm and one committee (consulting committee) that meets outside of that hour.

Learn more on our Instagram @netimpactslo and at our website. We look forward to seeing you soon!
Summary: Net Impact is a community dedicated to empowering students with opportunities to learn about and engage with the power of sustainable business as an agent for change.
CategoryNames: College of Agriculture, Food & Environmental Science

Name: New Student & Transition Programs
Description:
Cal Poly Orientation is a tradition that has helped welcome new Mustangs to campus, connect students, parents and supporters and community members to Cal Poly, and build life-long relationships for over 60 years. Recognized as one of the nation's best new student orientation programs, Cal Poly Orientation is the first step of every new student's Mustang journey that sets them up for academic, social and career success both during their time at Cal Poly and beyond.

Orientation at Cal Poly is made up of three major programs, each responsible for different events throughout the year. Select a program below to learn more.

Open House

Connect with the Cal Poly campus, current students and supporters, alumni, and the San Luis Obispo community in a weekend-long celebration of all Cal Poly and SLO do.

Student Life Orientation (SLO) Days

Get a taste of everything that our campus and a Cal Poly education have to offer in a two-day session.  We will be virtual during the month of July and transition to a hybrid format of some in-person components during August. All designed to get you ready for WOW in September!

Week of Welcome (WOW)

Week of Welcome kicks off the week prior to Fall Quarter.  Expect events with fun activities, relationship building and engaging presentations to get you ready to start your Cal Poly journey.
Summary: Cal Poly Orientation is a tradition that has helped welcome new Mustangs to campus, connect students, parents and supporters and community members to Cal Poly, and build life-long relationships for over 60 years.

Name: Newman Catholic Club
Description: The Newman Catholic Club is more than just a group; it’s a community where faith and friendship come alive! Whether you’re Catholic or simply curious, this is the perfect place to grow spiritually, connect with amazing people, and have fun along the way. From BBQs and epic game nights to inspiring Bible studies, men’s & women’s groups, retreats, and daily Mass, there’s always something happening. And trust us… that’s only the beginning!
Summary: We serve the students of Cal Poly through hosting weekly and quarterly events.

Name: Nikkei Student Union
Description:
Welcome!

Who are we

We are Nikkei Student Union, a Japanese/Japanese American cultural and social club that aims to develop positive social interactions within and outside the club, educate members on Japanese and Japanese American culture and history, and engage members in the community through service and volunteer opportunities.

Culture

Our hope is that members that come through our club will emerge with a greater understanding and appreciation for our culture and history, and we accomplish this through our weekly general meetings and annual events. Through student-led cultural presentations and workshops/presentations conducted by guest speakers, we cover a wide range of cultural topics such as life for Japanese Americans in the concentration camps, Japanese Americans in politics, Japanese holidays, traditions, and food, defining the term "Nikkei", and more. 

Service

We believe in not just learning about our culture and community, but also finding ways to give back, so another component of our club is doing service projects to serve the local Japanese American community or the greater AAPI community. Our club is also very hands-on, as we believe that the best way to get members to care about our club's mission is by having them actively serve in some capacity. Staff and leadership opportunities are readily available for members to step into, which not only increases the engagement of our members but also allows our club to sustain itself in future years.

Social

At the end of the day, we are a social club too, and we pride ourselves on finding the perfect balance between learning about our culture and having fun. We have fams to help our members get to know a smaller group of people on a deeper level, we have socials with other NSUs, and our general meetings often consist of games, competitions. Our bigger in-person events include potlucks, picnics, basketball tournaments with other NSUs and intramurals, family competitions, beach days, and more.

Basic Info

General Meetings: Tuesdays, 7:00-8:00 pm
Summary: NSU is an inclusive Japanese/Japanese American cultural and social club that aims to promote awareness of Japanese and Japanese American culture and engage members in the community.

Name: North Mountain Residence Halls
Description:
These five residence halls house first-year students.

 

• Shasta Hall
• Diablo Hall
• Palomar Hall
• Whitney Hall
• Lassen Hall

 

Residents have access to the game room, study lounge, and kitchen in the nearby South Mountain residence hall, Santa Lucia. Halls provide triple-occupancy accommodations with community-style bath facilities. Bedrooms and bathrooms are separated by gender unless the student specifically requests Queer-affirming housing.

 

North Mountain Residence Halls Virtual Tour

 

Map & Photos
Summary: North Mountain Residence Halls - Student Group: First years

Name: Nu Alpha Kappa
Description: We, NU ALPHA KAPPA, seek to unite and involve all students in a more harmonious and brotherly atmosphere through academic, social and cultural means. There is a need to interface the various backgrounds that constitute the student body of our fraternal university chapter, in order to improve relations amongst all students and the community.
Summary: We seek to unite and involve all students in a more harmonious atmosphere through academic, social and cultural means.

Name: Nuclear is Clean Energy
Description: We aim to educate club members, Cal Poly students, and members of the community about reactors, waste, and tech. Through events, public outreach, and talks we will engage with members of the public about the use of nuclear power in energy infrastructure. The ultimate goal of this club is to engage the campus community in a discussion of how best to use nuclear technology in the pursuit of a better world. We want to make science and energy science cool!
Summary: We aim to educate club members, Cal Poly students, and members of the community about reactors, waste, and tech. Through events, public outreach, and talks we will engage with members of the public about the use of nuclear power in energy infrastructure.
CategoryNames: College of Agriculture, Food & Environmental Science

Name: Nutrition Club
Description: Join our Groupme: https://groupme.com/join_group/89521932/ahNcl93F
Summary: Nutrition Club is a place for foodies and those with an interest in health and nutrition to meet, make connections, and learn more about jobs and opportunities in food and nutrition-related fields.
CategoryNames: College of Agriculture, Food & Environmental Science

Name: Off Campus Housing Program
Description:
The Off-Campus Housing Program was established to provide students and community stakeholders with connections and resources to improve student success as they live in the San Luis Obispo community. It is our goal to help students make an easy transition from on-campus to off-campus living, while encouraging them to become engaged, positive members of the community. 

We accomplish this by: 

  • Supporting students in making informed choices about off-campus housing, roommate selection, and tenant rights and responsibilities 

  • Encouraging students to become knowledgeable and responsible off-campus tenants and to promote neighborhood wellness 

  • Increasing student awareness of community values and responsibilities when living off-campus 

  • Creating and developing effective partnerships with key stakeholders in the San Luis Obispo community 

Find Off-Campus Housing resources here: https://deanofstudents.calpoly.edu/offcampushousing and follow us on Instagram for more tips!
Summary: Off-Campus Housing Program, Office of Dean of Students.

Name: Office of the Vice President for Strategic Enrollment Management and Student Affairs (SEMSA)
Description:
Welcome to the Division of Strategic Enrollment Management and Student Affairs (SEMSA)!

 

SEMSA supports every Mustang from admission through graduation. By uniting enrollment services with student life and holistic support, the division expands access, fosters belonging, and empowers students to succeed in all aspects of their Cal Poly journey. The Office of the Vice President provides leadership and coordination for this work across campus.

 

We invite you to learn more about our work, our mission, and our community of students! Get to know Strategic Enrollment Management and Student Affairs today! 

 

The Office of the Vice President for Strategic Enrollment Management and Student Affairs is located in the Administration Building (No. 1) and is open Monday through Friday, 8 a.m. to 5 p.m. Please adhere to public health guidelines before entering to support the health and wellbeing of our campus community.
Summary: Office of the Vice President for Strategic Enrollment Management and Student Affairs (SEMSA)

Name: Omicron Mu Chapter of the Chi Omega Fraternity
Description:
It all began on April 5, 1895 at the University of Arkansas when four young women, with the help of a local dentist, established the secrets and symbolism that today bond over 300,000 women. This small band of women founded Chi Omega after realizing a need for an organization that would foster both friendship and respect for the potential and inherent value of women. Over the years, Chi Omega has provided its members with unique opportunities in leadership, scholarship, and lifelong friendship - striving to provide each sister with a commitment to personal integrity, excellence in academic and intellectual pursuits, inter generational participation, community service, leadership opportunities and social enrichment.

Check our our 2020 recruitment video!
Summary: An Inclusive, Genuine, and Supportive Sisterhood that Celebrates Individuality and Advocates for Positive Change.

Name: One Health Club
Description: The One Health Club provides a platform to facilitate learning and collaboration between Cal Poly students and faculty working in comparative medicine, ecosystem health, disease ecology, public health, environmental justice, social sciences, wildlife conservation, and much more. Through field trips, training workshops, and speaker events, we connect students from diverse majors and backgrounds to graduate school and career opportunities that leverage skills across disciplines.
Summary: One Health is an integrative approach to solving complex global health issues connecting people, animals, and our shared environment.
CategoryNames: College of Agriculture, Food & Environmental Science

Name: Open House
Description: Hello! We are not currently recruiting for Open House. We will, however be looking for volunteers as Open House weekend approaches! Open House is April 7-9, 2022.
Summary: Cal Poly Open House 2021

Name: Orthodox Christian Fellowship of Cal Poly
Description: OCF cultivates a campus community of worship, witness, service, fellowship, and education.
Summary: Orthodox Christian Fellowship (OCF) is the official collegiate campus ministry program under the Assembly of Canonical Orthodox Bishops of the United States of America.

Name: Out in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (oSTEM)
Description: In a space where LGBTQ+ identities are often overlooked, Cal Poly’s oSTEM chapter strives to create a welcoming community for Queer engineers and scientists inside and outside of class. Through professional events, discussions between industry members and students, community spaces, outreach to local organizations and schools, and other forms of networking among the LGBTQ+ community, our oSTEM chapter will foster a more comfortable and inclusive space for queer people in STEM while focusing on the intersections of this community to ensure all members feel heard and empowered in STEM spaces at Cal Poly.
Summary: oSTEM provides a space for LGBTQ+ persons pursuing STEM degrees to connect and thrive through outreach events, professional development, and community building among individuals who are passionate about the intersection of the queer experience and STEM.
CategoryNames: College of Agriculture, Food & Environmental Science

Name: Packaging Club
Description: The Packaging Club (PKG) aims to connect students in the packaging concentration with peers, professors, alumni, and professionals and offer insight on career development within the packaging industry.
Summary: The Packaging Club (PKG) club aims to connect students in the packaging concentration with peers, professors, alumni, and professionals and offer insight on career development within the packaging industry.

Name: Parent and Family Programs
Summary: Parent and Family Programs provides support, resources and exciting programming for the proud parents, family members and supporters of Cal Poly students.

Name: Partners in Health Engage Cal Poly Club
Description:
Our club’s mission is rooted in the belief that health care is a human right, and we pursue this goal through three main branches: advocacy, community building and education, and fundraising.

Advocacy: We work to promote and secure the global right to health through targeted political action. By meeting with local and national leaders, we share lessons, stories, and outcomes from Partners In Health (PIH) sites, and champion legislation that removes barriers to care. We advocate for the radical but essential notion that people living in poverty deserve preferential access to high-quality health care.

Community Building and Education: Understanding the systemic inequities that drive poor health outcomes in impoverished countries is central to our work. Through curricula, webinars, discussions, and events, we raise awareness about the social and economic forces that undermine global health equity. By connecting poverty and health outcomes, we aim to cultivate an informed and engaged community dedicated to change.

Fundraising: We organize events and campaigns to provide PIH with resources to prevent unnecessary deaths and deliver care in some of the world’s poorest places. Beyond raising funds, we challenge traditional ideas of wealth and health care access, promoting a more just and equitable vision.

Each year, we focus our collective efforts on advancing the right to health. By advocating for justice, fundraising in solidarity with partner communities, and educating ourselves and others, we contribute to meaningful progress in global health equity.
Summary: Our club advances the right to health through advocacy, education, and fundraising. We champion health equity by engaging leaders, building informed communities, and supporting Partners In Health’s mission to deliver care in impoverished regions.

Name: Penguins Motorcycle Club
Summary: Motorcycle riding club, both dirt and street

Name: Phi Alpha Theta at Cal Poly
Summary: Phi Alpha Theta is a professional society for students interested in history. We promote the interest in history and connect students and faculty together through academic and social events.

Name: Phi Delta Theta Fraternity - California Nu Chapter
Description: Phi Delta Theta is the premier men’s leadership organization in North America, founded on December 25th, 1848 at Miami University based on three principles; Friendship, Sound Learning, and Rectitude. Guided by these values, Phi Delta Theta has expanded to almost 300 different campuses and has initiated more than 270,000 men across the United States and Canada to help every collegiate man become the greatest version of himself.
Summary: Phi Delta Theta is the pinnacle of fraternal and professional societies, centered on the potential of each brother, the unquenchable thirst for personal development and the lifelong values of friendship, sound learning and rectitude.

Name: Phi Gamma Delta
Description: Lambda Omicron Chapter
Summary: Phi Gamma Delta

Name: Phi Kappa Psi California Eta
Summary: Social Fraternity -Group of gentlemen banded together based on similar ideals and values. -Fraternity created in 1852 based on the great joy of serving others.

Name: Philosophy Club
Description:
Philosophy Club is an open forum for discussing all things intellectual, but with a special focus on philosophical topics of a slightly deeper nature than typically discussed in philosophy classes. Meetings take a seminar format, with students (or guests) volunteering to present their research on a particular area of philosophy to their peers, and then to moderate a discussion on the subject.

We teach the practical skills embodied in the ancient saying attributed to the rhetorician Quintilius: “vir bonus, dicendi peritus,” or “a good man (or woman!) who speaks well.”

Philosophy Club is a place where you can learn how to think on your feet, think critically (an apocryphal quote from Aristotle cites “the mark of an educated mind is to be able to entertain an idea without accepting it”), speak persuasively, disagree respectfully, and—most importantly—have fun while learning about the deep questions still facing humans.

 

All majors are welcome. 

Join our discord for regular updates on meeting topics, events, parties, and memes.
Summary: Come to Philosophy Club, where we share our philosophical research and discuss contemporary and historical philosophy, politics, and ideas. Open to all majors and all people with an open mind and a love of discussion.

Name: Pi Alpha Xi
Description: Pi Alpha Xi is the national honor society for floriculture, landscape horticulture, and ornamental horticulture. The society’s mission is to promote scholarship, fellowship, professional leadership, and the enrichment of human life through plants.
Summary: To promote the learning and love of horticulture and crop science through plants.
CategoryNames: College of Agriculture, Food & Environmental Science

Name: Pilipino Cultural Exchange
Description:
The Pilipino Cultural Exchange (PCE) is a student cultural organization at Cal Poly that prides itself on providing a home to anyone who seeks it. For over four decades now, our club has brought together a diverse, full spectrum of personalities, that celebrates Filipino culture while promoting cultural exchange!

You can learn more about us on our website! pcecpslo.com
Summary: The Pilipino Cultural Exchange (PCE) prides itself on providing a "home away from home" to anyone who seeks it. You do NOT need to be Filipino to join! All are welcome.

Name: Planned Parenthood Generation Action
Summary: Planned Parenthood Generation Action is the college affiliate of the Planned Parenthood Action Fund. We strive to create an organization that advocates for reproductive justice, freedom, and awareness. Come to build community and spread awareness!

Name: Plants, Peaks, Pals
Summary: Plants, Peaks and Pals is a club dedicated to helping fellow students learn more about the natural world around them including topics such as geology, botany, and ecology by inviting you and friends on hikes exploring the natural landscape of SLO county.

Name: Pokémon TCG  & VG Club
Description: The purpose for our Pokémon TCG & VG Club is to create a safe and welcoming space for anyone, weather you have have zero experience in playing or are far into your Pokémon journey to destress from class and personal life. Our community does this through socializing playing the Pokémon TCG(Trading Card Game), collecting and trading cards, and playing the VG(Video game). Meetings will consist of trading, opening packs of cards, playing the TCG, playing the VG, and even competing in in-house tournaments to win prizes!
Summary: A safe and welcoming space to learn and play the Pokémon TCG(Trading Card Game) & VG(Video Game), and collect cards with friends! Also including in-house tournaments to express your competitive spirit and win some prizes!

Name: Poly Canyon Village Apartments
Description:
Poly Canyon Village offers a vibrant community for first-year, transfer and continuing students at the foothills of Poly Canyon. Every apartment has a full kitchen, a living room common area, two bathrooms, and four, or five bedrooms. Bedrooms provide single-, double- and double-suite accommodations. Apartments can be single-gendered, mix-gendered or Queer-affirming.

 

Poly Canyon Village is made up of nine buildings:

 

• Aliso 
• Buena Vista
• Corralitos 
• Dover 
• Estrella

• Foxen 
• Gypsum 
• Huasna 
• Inyo 

 

Residents enjoy amenities like the Village Plaza in the heart of the community, complete with Einstein's Bros Bagels, Taco Bell, and the Market Poly Canyon. Nearby, a community center and leisure pool offer a chance to connect and unwind, while two adjacent parking structures make parking easy.

 

Poly Canyon Village Apartments Virtual Tour

 

Map & Photos
Summary: Poly Canyon Village Apartments - Student Groups: First year, Transfer, Graduate and Continuing students

Name: Poly Child Development Club
Summary: We are a club dedicated to serving children, each other, and the broader community by learning, volunteering, and going beyond the classroom.

Name: Poly Pups
Description: Poly Pups meets once a week to discuss and practice raising, socializing, and training our club puppies to be future guide dogs for the blind and visually impaired. Our club consists of puppy raisers, puppy sitters, and general club members. Puppy raisers have an assigned puppy that lives with them. They are the pup's primary raiser and trainer and take their puppy with them to classes, out shopping, and to other various outings when possible for socialization and training. Puppy sitters help the raisers by sitting pups when the raiser is unable, to support the raisers and give them breaks, and to help socialize the pup through working with new people and experiencing new routines. Sits can last anywhere from an hour to a few days, depending on the needs of the raiser and the availability of sitters. General club members attend weekly meetings along with the raisers and sitters and get hands-on practice handling, training, and socializing the pups during meetings. We also organize occasional club outings on the weekends for additional socialization and hand-on handling and training in new locations. Previous club outings have been trips to downtown SLO, Morro Bay, and Cal Poly baseball games. Poly Pups is a fun and impactful club with incredible members and adorable puppies!
Summary: Poly Pups is a volunteer puppy raising club for the non-profit organization Guide Dogs for the Blind. Poly Pups helps socialize and train future guide dogs for the blind and visually impared.

Name: Poly-Engineering Consulting
Description: The purpose of the Poly-Engineering Consulting (PEC) is to provide Cal Poly students interested in engineering with practical consulting experience across a variety of disciplines, majors, and interests. The organization aims to foster collaboration between students and industry professionals, promoting the exchange of knowledge and skills that students can carry forward into their careers. PEC facilitates hands-on, real-world problem-solving opportunities through partnerships with businesses, non-profits, and other organizations. It strives to create a professional community where students can develop essential leadership, teamwork, and consulting skills. The club is committed to promoting an inclusive environment that supports students of all backgrounds, encouraging diverse perspectives and innovative approaches. By bridging the gap between academic learning and professional practice, PEC provides students with valuable exposure to industry standards, expectations, and challenges. Additionally, the organization hosts workshops, seminars, and networking events designed to foster professional development and prepare members for careers in engineering and consulting.
Summary: PEC gives Cal Poly engineering students hands-on consulting experience across disciplines by partnering with industry and nonprofits to solve real challenges. It promotes leadership, diversity, and growth through workshops, seminars, and networking.

Name: PolyCon Tabletop Gaming
Description:
PolyCon meets every Friday from 5 p.m. to 10 p.m. in the BRAE building (building 8 room 122) to play board games, card games, and more together. During the beginning of the fall quarter we host a Find Your GM Night where we help to match aspiring GMs for tabletop role-playing games with players from all across campus. All announcements and updates are sent through Instagram and Discord. Everyone is welcome!

Follow us on Instagram: @polycongaming

Join us on Discord: https://discord.gg/twn7FvpRus
Summary: PolyCon Tabletop Gaming hosts weekly gaming events where members play board games, card games, and tabletop RPGs. We also run one gaming convention each quarter, with fall and winter being one day events and spring being a whole weekend.

Name: PolyGoats Four-Wheel Drive Club
Description: A 60-year-old four-wheel drive club for members interested in off-road vehicles, exploring, and camping across California. The club members also help each other with all kinds of mechanical/off-road related projects with their vehicles.
Summary: A four-wheel drive club for members interested in off-road vehicles. Members also help each other work on their cars.

Name: PolySmiths
Description: Students will learn the unique and varied skills involved in smithing along with proper forge safety. Outside of an advanced materials class, students get the unique opportunity to learn about metallurgy and its application in blacksmithing. Our club also promotes recycling and repurposing useful materials for any type of project.  New smiths need only their time and passion to learn the wide range of skills involved. Art, engineering and all the like of students are encouraged to join.
Summary: PolySmiths is a club dedicated to the art of blacksmithing and all skills associated with the craft.

Name: Power and Energy Society
Description: The student chapter of the Power and Energy Society at Cal Poly San Luis Obispo strives to provide its members with knowledge and experience with technological developments in the electric power industry. Our goal is to develop the professionalism required for future internship and employment opportunities. We provide educational opportunities such as industry tours, information sessions, and technical talks.
Summary: Power and Energy Society works to build Cal Poly students' knowledge of the Electric Power industry through opportunities to interact with industrial professionals, industry tours, information sessions, and technical talks.

Name: Pre-PT/OT Club
Description:
• Cal Poly SLO’s Physical Therapy and Occupational Therapy Club strives to create a social network between students, faculty, alumni, and professionals. We provide an opportunity for Cal Poly SLO students interested in Physical or Occupational Therapy to learn, socialize, and interact with one another.
  • The club aims to help students with the application process and make sure they understand all the requirements so the can successfully apply without setbacks when the time comes.
Summary: Cal Poly's Pre-Physical Therapy and Occupational Therapy Club fosters connections among students, faculty, alumni, and professionals. We offer networking, educational events, and resources to support students pursuing careers in PT/OT and related fields.

Name: Precision Agriculture and Automation Club
Summary: PAAC is a multidisciplinary engineering club that enables students to explore automation in agriculture. The club focuses on learning what it takes to build, design, and code a robot. Students can focus on one or all aspects, so everyone can help.
CategoryNames: College of Agriculture, Food & Environmental Science

Name: Pride Center (LGBTQIA2S)
Description:
Centering the experiences of queer, transgender, and non-binary people of color, the pride center crafts events supporting and empowering people of all sexual orientations, gender identities, expressions, and racial identities. With an emphasis on three core values: intersectional justice, community empowerment, and promoting authentic boldness. We invite the Cal Poly campus community to explore dismantling heteronormativity and the legacy of colonization. Pride envisions a community where people can openly explore their own understanding of gender and sexuality. 

 

Location: 

University Union, Building 65, Room 217  

Operating Hours: 

Staffed Hours: 9:00am-5:00pm 

Monday-Friday 

Center Space Hours: General University Union Hours. 

Center Space Offerings: 

Printing, snacks, sleeping, crafting, library, and desktops. 

 

Our programming consists of quarterly and signature events. Below are examples of some past events. 

T-Party:  

This is a Trans and non-binary community space. It included a podcast circle, a craft circle, and a movie screening with Cal Poly Safer and the Native American and Indigenous Cultural Center. 

Coming Out Week: 

A week that highlights the coming out experience in our community. It includes panels and time for the community to share their experiences. 

Pride Prom: 

This is an annual event that allows our students to experience prom in ways they may not have before.  

Winter wonderland Drag Show: 

This event was one of the drag shows we host throughout the year. 

Pride Ballroom: 

Our brand-new ballroom event was in collaboration with BAEC, NAICC, LA CASA and MCC. This was an opportunity to celebrate the history and celebration that was created by QTPOC. At this event we had 4 houses and 4 categories to walk the runway for the judges and the crowd. This year's inspiration: CAMP.
